Text: And if any one have caused grief, he hath not grieved me: but in part, that I may not burden you all.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To him who is such a one, this rebuke is sufficient, which is given by many.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So that on the contrary, you should rather forgive him and comfort him, lest perhaps such a one be swallowed up with overmuch sorrow.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, I beseech you that you would confirm your charity towards him.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For to this end also did I write, that I may know the experiment of you, whether you be obedient in all things.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And to whom you have pardoned any thing, I also. For, what I have pardoned, if I have pardoned any thing, for your sakes have I done it in the person of Christ: I also.... The apostle here granted an indulgence, or pardon, in the person and by the authority of Christ, to the incestuous Corinthian, whom before he had put under penance, which pardon consisted in a releasing of part of the temporal punishment due to his sin.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That we be not overreached by Satan. For we are not ignorant of his devices.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And when I was come to Troas for the gospel of Christ and a door was opened unto me in the Lord,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I had no rest in my spirit, because I found not Titus my brother: but bidding them farewell, I went into Macedonia.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now thanks be to God, who always maketh us to triumph in Christ Jesus and manifesteth the odour of his knowledge by us in every place.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we are the good odour of Christ unto God, in them that are saved and in them that perish.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To the one indeed the odour of death unto death: but to the others the odour of life unto life. And for these things who is so sufficient? The odour of death, etc.... The preaching of the apostle, which by its fragrant odour, brought many to life, was to others, through their own fault, the occasion of death; by their wilfully opposing and resisting that divine call.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we are not as many, adulterating the word of God: but with sincerity: but as from God, before God, in Christ we speak. 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 He needs no commendatory letters. The glory of the ministry of the New Testament.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Do we begin again to commend ourselves? Or do we need (as some do) epistles of commendation to you, or from you?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are our epistle, written in our hearts, which is known and read by all men:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Being manifested, that you are the epistle of Christ, ministered by us, and written: not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God: not in tables of stone but in the fleshly tables of the heart.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And such confidence we have, through Christ, towards God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Not that we are sufficient to think any thing of ourselves, as of ourselves: but our sufficiency is from God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who also hath made us fit ministers of the new testament, not in the letter but in the spirit. For the letter killeth: but the spirit quickeneth. The letter.... Not rightly understood, and taken without the spirit.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now if the ministration of death, engraven with letters upon stones, was glorious (so that the children of Israel could not steadfastly behold the face of Moses, for the glory of his countenance), which is made void:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: How shall not the ministration of the spirit be rather in glory?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if the ministration of condemnation be glory, much more the ministration of justice aboundeth in glory.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For even that which was glorious in this part was not glorified by reason of the glory that excelleth.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if that which is done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is in glory.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Having therefore such hope, we use much confidence.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And not as Moses put a veil upon his face, that the children of Israel might not steadfastly look on the face of that which is made void.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But their senses were made dull. For, until this present day, the selfsame veil, in the reading of the old testament, remaineth not taken away (because in Christ it is made void).

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But even until this day, when Moses is read, the veil is upon their heart.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But when they shall be converted to the Lord, the veil shall be taken away.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now the Lord is a Spirit. And where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we all, beholding the glory of the Lord with open face, are transformed into the same image from glory to glory, as by the Spirit of the Lord. 2 Corinthians Chapter 4 The sincerity of his preaching. His comfort in his afflictions.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore seeing we have this ministration, according as we have obtained mercy, we faint not.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we renounce the hidden things of dishonesty, not walking in craftiness nor adulterating the word of God: but by manifestation of the truth commending ourselves to every man’s conscience, in the sight of God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if our gospel be also hid, it is hid to them that are lost,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In whom the god of this world hath blinded the minds of unbelievers, that the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God, should not shine unto them.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we preach not ourselves, but Jesus Christ our Lord: and ourselves your servants through Jesus.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God, in the face of Christ Jesus.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency may be of the power of God and not of us.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In all things we suffer tribulation: but are not distressed. We are straitened: but are not destitute.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We suffer persecution: but are not forsaken. We are cast down: but we perish not.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Always bearing about in our body the mortification of Jesus, that the life also of Jesus may be made manifest in our bodies.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we who live are always delivered unto death for Jesus’ sake: that the life also of Jesus may be made manifest in our mortal flesh.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So then death worketh in us: but life in you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But having the same spirit of faith, as it is written: I believed, for which cause I have spoken; we also believe. For which cause we speak also:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Knowing that he who raised up Jesus will raise us up also with Jesus and place us with you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For all things are for your sakes: that the grace, abounding through many, may abound in thanksgiving unto the glory of God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For which cause we faint not: but though our outward man is corrupted, yet the inward man is renewed day by day.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For that which is at present momentary and light of our tribulation worketh for us above measure, exceedingly an eternal weight of glory.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen. For the things which are seen are temporal: but the things which are not seen, are eternal. 2 Corinthians Chapter 5 He is willing to leave his earthly mansion to be with the Lord. His charity to the Corinthians.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we know, if our earthly house of this habitation be dissolved, that we have a building of God, a house not made with hands, eternal in heaven.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For in this also we groan, desiring to be clothed upon with our habitation that is from heaven.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yet so that we be found clothed, not naked.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we also, who are in this tabernacle, do groan, being burthened; because we would not be unclothed, but clothed upon, that that which is mortal may be swallowed up by life.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now he that maketh us for this very thing is God, who hath given us the pledge of the Spirit,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore having always confidence, knowing that while we are in the body we are absent from the Lord.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: (For we walk by faith and not by sight.)

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we are confident and have a good will to be absent rather from the body and to be present with the Lord.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And therefore we labour, whether absent or present, to please him.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we must all be manifested before the judgment seat of Christ, that every one may receive the proper things of the body, according as he hath done, whether it be good or evil. The proper things of the body.... In the particular judgment, immediately after death, the soul is rewarded or punished according to what it has done in the body.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Knowing therefore the fear of the Lord, we use persuasion to men: but to God we are manifest. And I trust also that in your consciences we are manifest.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We commend not ourselves again to you, but give you occasion to glory in our behalf: that you may have somewhat to answer them who glory in face, and not in heart.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For whether we be transported in mind, it is to God: or whether we be sober, it is for you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the charity of Christ presseth us: judging this, that if one died for all, then all were dead.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And Christ died for all: that they also who live may not now live to themselves, but unto him who died for them and rose again.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore henceforth, we know no man according to the flesh. And if we have known Christ according to the flesh: but now we know him so no longer. We know no man according to the flesh.... That is, we consider not any man with regard to his nation, family, kindred, or other natural qualities or advantages; but only with relation to Christ, and according to the order of divine charity, in God, and for God. The apostle adds, that even with respect to Christ himself, he now no longer considers him according to the flesh, by taking a satisfaction in his being his countryman; his affection being now purified from all such earthly considerations.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If then any be in Christ a new creature, the old things are passed away. Behold all things are made new.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Christ and hath given to us the ministry of reconciliation.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For God indeed was in Christ, reconciling the world to himself, not imputing to them their sins. And he hath placed in us the word of reconciliation.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For Christ therefore we are ambassadors, God as it were exhorting by us, for Christ, we beseech you, be reconciled to God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Him, who knew no sin, he hath made sin for us: that we might be made the justice of God in him. Sin for us.... That is, to be a sin offering, a victim for sin. 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 He exhorts them to a correspondence with God’s grace and not to associate with unbelievers.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And we helping do exhort you that you receive not the grace of God in vain.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he saith: In an accepted time have I heard thee and in the day of salvation have I helped thee. Behold, now is the acceptable time: behold, now is the day of salvation.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Giving no offence to any man, that our ministry be not blamed.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But in all things let us exhibit ourselves as the ministers of God, in much patience, in tribulation, in necessities, in distresses,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In stripes, in prisons, in seditions, in labours, in watchings, in fastings,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In chastity, in knowledge, in longsuffering, in sweetness, in the Holy Ghost, in charity unfeigned,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In the word of truth, in the power of God: by the armour of justice on the right hand and on the left:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: By honour and dishonour: by evil report and good report: as deceivers and yet true: as unknown and yet known:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As dying and behold we live: as chastised and not killed:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As sorrowful, yet always rejoicing: as needy, yet enriching many: as having nothing and possessing all things.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Our mouth is open to you, O ye Corinthians: our heart is enlarged.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are not straitened in us: but in your own bowels you are straitened.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But having the same recompense (I speak as to my children): be you also enlarged.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Bear not the yoke with unbelievers. For what participation hath justice with injustice? Or what fellowship hath light with darkness?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And what concord hath Christ with Belial? Or what part hath the faithful with the unbeliever?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And what agreement hath the temple of God with idols? For you are the temple of the living God: as God saith: I will dwell in them and walk among them. And I will be their God: and they shall be my people.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore: Go out from among them and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I will receive you. And will be a Father to you: and you shall be my sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty. 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 The apostle’s affection for the Corinthians. His comfort and joy on their account.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Having therefore these promises, dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all defilement of the flesh and of the spirit, perfecting sanctification in the fear of God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Receive us. We have injured no man: we have corrupted no man: we have overreached no man.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak not this to your condemnation. For we have said before that you are in our hearts: to die together and to live together.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Great is my confidence for you: great is my glorying for you. I am filled with comfort: I exceedingly abound with joy in all our tribulation.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For also, when we were come into Macedonia, our flesh had no rest: but we suffered all tribulation. Combats without: fears within.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But God, who comforteth the humble, comforted us by the coming of Titus.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And not by his coming only, but also by the consolation wherewith he was comforted in you, relating to us your desire, your mourning, your zeal for me: so that I rejoiced the more.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For although I made you sorrowful by my epistle, I do not repent. And if I did repent, seeing that the same epistle (although but for a time) did make you sorrowful,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I am glad: not because you were made sorrowful, but because you were made sorrowful unto penance. For you were made sorrowful according to God, that you might suffer damage by us in nothing.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the sorrow that is according to God worketh penance, steadfast unto salvation: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For behold this selfsame thing, that you were made sorrowful according to God, how great carefulness it worketh in you: yea defence, yea indignation, yea fear, yea desire, yea zeal, yea revenge. In all things you have shewed yourselves to be undefiled in the matter.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore although I wrote to you, it was not for his sake that did the wrong, nor for him that suffered it: but to manifest our carefulness that we have for you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Before God: therefore we were comforted. But in our consolation we did the more abundantly rejoice for the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by you all.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if I have boasted any thing to him of you, I have not been put to shame: but as we have spoken all things to you in truth, so also our boasting that was made to Titus is found a truth.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And his bowels are more abundantly towards you: remembering the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling you received him.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I rejoice that in all things I have confidence in you. 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 He exhorts them to contribute bountifully to relieve the poor of Jerusalem.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now we make known unto you, brethren, the grace of God that hath been given in the churches of Macedonia.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That in much experience of tribulation, they have had abundance of joy and their very deep poverty hath abounded unto the riches of their simplicity. Simplicity.... That is, sincere bounty and charity.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For according to their power (I bear them witness) and beyond their power, they were willing:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: With much entreaty begging of us the grace and communication of the ministry that is done toward the saints.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And not as we hoped: but they gave their own selves, first to the Lord, then to us by the will of God;

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Insomuch, that we desired Titus, that, as he had begun, so also he would finish among you this same grace.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That as in all things you abound in faith and word and knowledge and all carefulness, moreover also in your charity towards us: so in this grace also you may abound.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak not as commanding: but by the carefulness of others, approving also the good disposition of your charity.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that being rich he became poor for your sakes: that through his poverty you might be rich.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And herein I give my advice: for this is profitable for you who have begun not only to do but also to be willing, a year ago.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now therefore perform ye it also in deed: that as your mind is forward to be willing, so it may be also to perform, out of that which you have.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if the will be forward, it is accepted according to that which a man hath: not according to that which he hath not.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I mean not that others should be eased and you burdened, but by an equality.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In this present time let your abundance supply their want, that their abundance also may supply your want: that there may be an equality,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As it is written: He that had much had nothing over; and he that had little had no want.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And thanks be to God, who hath given the same carefulness for you in the heart of Titus.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For indeed he accepted the exhortation: but, being more careful, of his own will he went unto you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We have sent also with him the brother whose praise is in the gospel through all the churches.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And not that only: but he was also ordained by the churches companion of our travels, for this grace, which is administered by us, to the glory of the Lord and our determined will:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Avoiding this, lest any man should blame us in this abundance which is administered by us.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we forecast what may be good, not only before God but also before men.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And we have sent with them our brother also, whom we have often proved diligent in many things, but now much more diligent: with much confidence in you,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Either for Titus, who is my companion and fellow labourer towards you, or our brethren, the apostles of the churches, the glory of Christ.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore shew ye to them, in the sight of the churches, the evidence of your charity and of our boasting on your behalf. 2 Corinthians Chapter 9 A further exhortation to almsgiving. The fruits of it.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For concerning the ministry that is done towards the saints, it is superfluous for me to write unto you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I know your forward mind: for which I boast of you to the Macedonians, that Achaia also is ready from the year past. And your emulation hath provoked very many.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I have sent the brethren, that the thing which we boast of concerning you be not made void in this behalf, that (as I have said) you may be ready:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Lest, when the Macedonians shall come with me and find you unprepared, we (not to say ye) should be ashamed in this matter.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore I thought it necessary to desire the brethren that they would go to you before and prepare this blessing before promised, to be ready, so as a blessing, not as covetousness.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I say: He who soweth sparingly shall also reap sparingly: and he who soweth in blessings shall also reap blessings.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Every one as he hath determined in his heart, not with sadness or of necessity: for God loveth a cheerful giver.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And God is able to make all grace abound in you: that ye always, having all sufficiency in all things, may abound to every good work,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As it is written: He hath dispersed abroad, he hath given to the poor: his justice remaineth for ever.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And he that ministereth seed to the sower will both give you bread to eat and will multiply your seed and increase the growth of the fruits of your justice:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That being enriched in all things, you may abound unto all simplicity which worketh through us thanksgiving to God.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Because the administration of this office doth not only supply the want of the saints, but aboundeth also by many thanksgivings in the Lord.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: By the proof of this ministry, glorifying God for the obedience of your confession unto the gospel of Christ and for the simplicity of your communicating unto them and unto all.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And in their praying for you, being desirous of you, because of the excellent grace of God in you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift. 2 Corinthians Chapter 10 To stop the calumny and boasting of false apostles, he set forth the power of his apostleship.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I Paul, myself beseech you, by the mildness and modesty of Christ: who in presence indeed am lowly among you, but being absent am bold toward you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I beseech you, that I may not be bold when I am present with that confidence wherewith I am thought to be bold, against some who reckon us as if we walked according to the flesh.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war according to the flesh.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal but mighty to God, unto the pulling down of fortifications, destroying counsels,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And every height that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God: and bringing into captivity every understanding unto the obedience of Christ:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And having in readiness to revenge all disobedience, when your obedience shall be fulfilled.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: See the things that are according to outward appearance. If any man trust to himself, that he is Christ’s let him think this again with himself, that as he is Christ’s, so are we also.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if also I should boast somewhat more of our power, which the Lord hath given us unto edification and not for your destruction, I should not be ashamed.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But that I may not be thought as it were to terrify you by epistles,

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: (For his epistles indeed, say they, are weighty and strong; but his bodily presence is weak and his speech contemptible):

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let such a one think this, that such as we are in word by epistles when absent, such also we will be indeed when present.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we dare not match or compare ourselves with some that commend themselves: but we measure ourselves by ourselves and compare ourselves with ourselves.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we will not glory beyond our measure: but according to the measure of the rule which God hath measured to us, a measure to reach even unto you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we stretch not ourselves beyond our measure, as if we reached not unto you. For we are come as far as to you in the Gospel of Christ.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Not glorying beyond measure in other men’s labours: but having hope of your increasing faith, to be magnified in you according to our rule abundantly.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yea, unto those places that are beyond you to preach the gospel: not to glory in another man’s rule, in those things that are made ready to our hand.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For not he who commendeth himself is approved: but he, whom God commendeth. 2 Corinthians Chapter 11 He is forced to commend himself and his labours, lest the Corinthians should be imposed upon by the false apostles.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Would to God you could bear with some little of my folly! But do bear with me. My folly.... So he calls his reciting his own praises, which, commonly speaking is looked upon as a piece of folly and vanity; though the apostle was constrained to do it, for the good of the souls committed to his charge.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I am jealous of you with the jealousy of God. For I have espoused you to one husband, that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I fear lest, as the serpent seduced Eve by his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted and fall from the simplicity that is in Christ.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if he that cometh preacheth another Christ, whom we have not preached; or if you receive another Spirit, whom you have not received; or another gospel, which you have not received: you might well bear with him.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I suppose that I have done nothing less than the great apostles.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For although I be rude in speech, yet not in knowledge: but in all things we have been made manifest to you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or did I commit a fault, humbling myself that you might be exalted, because I preached unto you the Gospel of God freely?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I have taken from other churches, receiving wages of them for your ministry.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And, when I was present with you and wanted, I was chargeable to no man: for that which was wanting to me, the brethren supplied who came from Macedonia. And in all things I have kept myself from being burthensome to you: and so I will keep myself.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The truth of Christ is in me, that this glorying shall not be broken off in me in the regions of Achaia.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore? Because I love you not? God knoweth it.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But what I do, that I will do: that I may cut off the occasion from them that desire occasion: that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For such false apostles are deceitful workmen, transforming themselves into the apostles of Christ.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And no wonder: for Satan himself transformeth himself into an angel of light.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore it is no great thing if his ministers be transformed as the ministers of justice, whose end shall be according to their works.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I say again (Let no man think me to be foolish: otherwise take me as one foolish, that I also may glory a little):

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That which I speak, I speak not according to God: but as it were in foolishness, in this matter of glorying.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Seeing that many glory according to the flesh, I will glory also.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you gladly suffer the foolish: whereas yourselves are wise.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you suffer if a man bring you into bondage, if a man devour you, if a man take from you, if a man be lifted up, if a man strike you on the face.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak according to dishonour, as if we had been weak in this part. Wherein if any man dare (I speak foolishly), I dare also.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: They are Hebrews: so am I. They are Israelites: so am I. They are the seed of Abraham: so am I.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: They are the ministers of Christ (I speak as one less wise): I am more; in many more labours, in prisons more frequently, in stripes above measure, in deaths often.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Of the Jews five times did I receive forty stripes save one.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Thrice was I beaten with rods: once I was stoned: thrice I suffered shipwreck: a night and a day I was in the depth of the sea.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In journeying often, in perils of waters, in perils of robbers, in perils from my own nation, in perils from the Gentiles, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness, in perils in the sea, in perils from false brethren:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In labour and painfulness, in much watchings, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often, in cold and nakedness:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Besides those things which are without: my daily instance, the solicitude for all the churches. My daily instance.... The labours that come in, and press upon me every day.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is scandalized, and I am not on fire?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If I must needs glory, I will glory of the things that concern my infirmity.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed for ever, knoweth that I lie not.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: At Damascus, the governor of the nation under Aretas the king, guarded the city of the Damascenes, to apprehend me.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And through a window in a basket was I let down by the wall: and so escaped his hands. 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 His raptures and revelations, His being buffeted by Satan. His fear for the Corinthians.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If I must glory (it is not expedient indeed) but I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I know a man in Christ: above fourteen years ago (whether in the body, I know not, or out of the body, I know not: God knoweth), such a one caught up to the third heaven.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I know such a man (whether in the body, or out of the body, I know not: God knoweth):

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That he was caught up into paradise and heard secret words which it is not granted to man to utter.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For such an one I will glory: but for myself I will glory nothing but in my infirmities.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For though I should have a mind to glory, I shall not be foolish: for I will say the truth. But I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he seeth in me, or any thing he heareth from me.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And lest the greatness of the revelations should exalt me, there was given me a sting of my flesh, an angel of Satan, to buffet me.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For which thing, thrice I besought the Lord that it might depart from me.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And he said to me: My grace is sufficient for thee: for power is made perfect in infirmity. Gladly therefore will I glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may dwell in me. Power is made perfect.... The strength and power of God more perfectly shines forth in our weakness and infirmity; as the more weak we are of ourselves, the more illustrious is his grace in supporting us, and giving us the victory under all trials and conflicts.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For which cause I please myself in my infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses, for Christ. For when I am weak, then am I powerful.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I am become foolish. You have compelled me: for I ought to have been commended by you. For I have no way come short of them that are above measure apostles, although I be nothing.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yet the signs of my apostleship have been wrought on you, in all patience, in signs and wonders and mighty deeds.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For what is there that you have had less than the other churches but that I myself was not burthensome to you? Pardon me this injury.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Behold now the third time I am ready to come to you and I will not be burthensome unto you. For I seek not the things that are yours, but you. For neither ought the children to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I most gladly will spend and be spent myself for your souls: although loving you more, I be loved less.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But be it so: I did not burthen you: but being crafty, I caught you by guile.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Did I overreach you by any of them whom I sent to you?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I desired Titus: and I sent with him a brother. Did Titus overreach you? Did we not walk with the same spirit? Did we not in the same steps?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Of old, think you that we excuse ourselves to you? We speak before God in Christ: but all things, my dearly beloved, for your edification.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I fear lest perhaps, when I come, I shall not find you such as I would, and that I shall be found by you such as you would not. Lest perhaps contentions, envyings, animosities, dissensions, detractions, whisperings, swellings, seditions, be among you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Lest again, when I come, God humble me among you: and I mourn many of them that sinned before and have not done penance for the uncleanness and fornication and lasciviousness that they have committed. 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 He threatens the impenitent, to provoke them to penance.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Behold, this is the third time I am coming to you: In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word stand.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I have told before and foretell, as present and now absent, to them that sinned before and to all the rest, that if I come again, I will not spare.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Do you seek a proof of Christ that speaketh in me, who towards you is not weak, but is mighty in you?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For although he was crucified through weakness, yet he liveth by the power of God. For we also are weak in him: but we shall live with him by the power of God towards you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Try your own selves if you be in the faith: prove ye yourselves. Know you not your own selves, that Christ Jesus is in you, unless perhaps you be reprobates?

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I trust that you shall know that we are not reprobates.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now we pray God that you may do no evil, not that we may appear approved, but that you may do that which is good and that we may be as reprobates. Reprobates.... that is, without proof, by having no occasion of shewing our power in punishing you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we can do nothing against the truth: but for the truth.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we rejoice that we are weak and you are strong. This also we pray for, your perfection.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore I write these things, being absent, that, being present, I may not deal more severely, according to the power which the Lord hath given me unto edification and not unto destruction.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the rest, brethren, rejoice, be perfect, take exhortation, be of one mind, have peace. And the God of peace and of love shall be with you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Salute one another with a holy kiss. All the saints salute you.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ and the charity of God and the communication of the Holy Ghost be with you all. Amen.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The burden of Ninive. The book of the vision of Nahum, the Elcesite.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The Lord is a jealous God, and a revenger: the Lord is a revenger, and hath wrath: the Lord taketh vengeance on his adversaries, and he is angry with his enemies.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The Lord is patient, and great in power, and will not cleanse and acquit the guilty. The Lord’s ways are in a tempest, and a whirlwind, and clouds are the dust of his feet.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: He rebuketh the sea and drieth it up: and bringeth all the rivers to be a desert. Basan languisheth and Carmel: and the flower of Libanus fadeth away.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The mountains tremble at him, and the hills are made desolate: and the earth hath quaked at his presence, and the world, and all that dwell therein.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Who can stand before the face of his indignation? and who shall resist in the fierceness of his anger? his indignation is poured out like fire: and the rocks are melted by him.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The Lord is good, and giveth strength in the day of trouble: and knoweth them that hope in him.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: But with a flood that passeth by, he will make an utter end of the place thereof: and darkness shall pursue his enemies. Of the place thereof.... Viz., of Ninive.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: What do ye devise against the Lord? he will make an utter end: there shall not rise a double affliction.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: For as thorns embrace one another: so while they are feasting and drinking together, they shall be consumed as stubble that is fully dry.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Out of thee shall come forth one that imagineth evil against the Lord, contriving treachery in his mind. Shall come forth one, etc.... Some understand this of Sennacherib. But as his attempt against the people seems to have been prior to the prophecy of Nahum, we may better understand it of Holofernes.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Thus saith the Lord: Though they were perfect: and many of them so, yet thus shall they be cut off, and he shall pass: I have afflicted thee, and I will afflict thee no more. Though they were perfect, etc.... That is, however strong or numerous their forces may be, they shall be cut off; and their prince or leader shall pass away and disappear.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And now I will break in pieces his rod with which he struck thy back, and I will burst thy bonds asunder.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And the Lord will give a commandment concerning thee, that no more of thy name shall be sown: I will destroy the graven and molten thing out of the house of thy God, I will make it thy grave, for thou art disgraced. Will give a commandment.... That is, a decree, concerning thee, O king of Ninive, thy seed shall fail, etc.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Behold upon the mountains the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, and that preacheth peace: O Juda, keep thy festivals, and pay thy vows: for Belial shall no more pass through thee again, he is utterly cut off. Belial.... The wicked one, viz., the Assyrian. Nahum Chapter 2 God sends his armies against Ninive to destroy it.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: He is come up that shall destroy before thy face, that shall keep the siege: watch the way, fortify thy loins, strengthen thy power exceedingly.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: For the Lord hath rendered the pride of Jacob, as the pride of Israel: because the spoilers have laid them waste, and have marred their vine branches. Hath rendered the pride of Jacob, etc.... He hath punished Jacob for his pride; and therefore Ninive must not expect to escape. Or else, rendering the pride of Jacob means rewarding, that is, punishing Ninive for the pride they exercised against Jacob.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The shield of his mighty men is like fire, the men of the army are clad in scarlet, the reins of the chariot are flaming in the day of his preparation, and the drivers are stupefied. Of his mighty men, etc.... He speaks of the Chaldeans and Medes sent to destroy Ninive.—Ibid. Stupefied.... consopiti. That is, they drive on furiously like men intoxicated with wine.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: They are in confusion in the ways, the chariots jostle one against another in the streets: their looks are like torches, like lightning running to and fro.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: He will muster up his valiant men, they shall stumble in their march: they shall quickly get upon the walls thereof: and a covering shall be prepared. Stumble in their march.... By running hastily on.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The gates of the rivers are opened, and the temple is thrown down to the ground.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And the soldier is led away captive: and her bondwomen were led away mourning as doves, murmuring in their hearts.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And as for Ninive, her waters are like a great pool: but the men flee away. They cry: Stand, stand, but there is none that will return back.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Take ye the spoil of the silver, take the spoil of the gold: for there is no end of the riches of all the precious furniture.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: She is destroyed, and rent, and torn: the heart melteth, and the knees fail, and all the loins lose their strength: and the faces of them all are as the blackness of a kettle.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Where is now the dwelling of the lions, and the feeding place of the young lions, to which the lion went, to enter in thither, the young lion, and there was none to make them afraid?

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The lion caught enough for his whelps, and killed for his lionesses: and he filled his holes with prey, and his den with rapine.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Behold I come against thee, saith the Lord of hosts, and I will burn thy chariots even to smoke, and the sword shall devour thy young lions: and I will cut off thy prey out of the land, and the voice of thy messengers shall be heard no more. Nahum Chapter 3 The miserable destruction of Ninive.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Woe to thee, O city of blood, all full of lies and violence: rapine shall not depart from thee.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: The noise of the whip, and the noise of the rattling of the wheels, and of the neighing horse; and of the running chariot, and of the horsemen coming up,

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And of the shining sword, and of the glittering spear, and of a multitude slain, and of a grievous destruction: and there is no end of carcasses, and they shall fall down on their dead bodies.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Because of the multitude of the fornications of the harlot that was beautiful and agreeable, and that made use of witchcraft, that sold nations through her fornications, and families through her witchcrafts.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Behold I come against thee, saith the Lord of hosts: and I will discover thy shame to thy face, and will shew thy nakedness to the nations, and thy shame to kingdoms.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And I will cast abominations upon thee, and will disgrace thee, and will make an example of thee.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: And it shall come to pass that every one that shall see thee, shall flee from thee, and shall say: Ninive is laid waste: who shall bemoan thee? whence shall I seek a comforter for thee?

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Art thou better than the populous Alexandria, that dwelleth among the rivers? waters are round about it: the sea is its riches: the waters are its walls. Populous Alexandria.... No-Ammon. A populous city of Egypt destroyed by the Chaldeans, and afterwards rebuilt by Alexander, and called Alexandria. Others suppose No-Ammon to be the same as Diospolis.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Ethiopia and Egypt were the strength thereof, and there is no end: Africa and the Libyans were thy helpers.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Yet she also was removed and carried into captivity: her young children were dashed in pieces at the top of every street, and they cast lots upon her nobles, and all her great men were bound in fetters.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Therefore thou also shalt be made drunk, and shalt be despised: and thou shalt seek help from the enemies.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: All thy strong holds shall be like fig trees with their green figs: if they be shaken, they shall fall into the mouth of the eater.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Behold thy people in the midst of thee are women: the gates of thy land shall be set wide open to thy enemies, the fire shall devour thy bars.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Draw thee water for the siege, build up thy bulwarks: go into the clay, and tread, work it and make brick.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: There shall the fire devour thee: thou shalt perish by the sword, it shall devour thee like the bruchus: assemble together like the bruchus, make thyself many like the locust.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Thou hast multiplied thy merchandises above the stars of heaven: the bruchus hath spread himself and flown away.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Thy guards are like the locusts: and thy little ones like the locusts of locusts which swarm on the hedges in the day of cold: the sun arose, and they flew away, and their place was not known where they were. Locusts of locusts.... The young locusts.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Thy shepherds have slumbered, O king of Assyria, thy princes shall be buried: thy people are hid in the mountains, and there is none to gather them.

Book: The Prophecy of Nahum
Text: Thy destruction is not hidden, thy wound is grievous: all that have heard the fame of thee, have clapped their hands over thee: for upon whom hath not thy wickedness passed continually?

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: The Ancient, to the dearly beloved Gaius, whom I love in truth.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, concerning all things I make it my prayer that thou mayest proceed prosperously and fare well, as thy soul doth prosperously.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I was exceedingly glad when the brethren came and gave testimony to the truth in thee, even as thou walkest in the truth.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I have no greater grace than this, to hear that my children walk in truth. No greater grace.... that is nothing that gives me greater joy and satisfaction.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, thou dost faithfully whatever thou dost for the brethren: and that for strangers,

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Who have given testimony to thy charity in the sight of the church. Whom thou shalt do well to bring forward on their way in a manner worthy of God:

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Because, for his name they went out, taking nothing of the Gentiles. Taking nothing of the Gentiles.... These ministers of the gospel are commended by St. John, who took nothing from the Gentiles, lest they should seem to preach in order to get money by it.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: We therefore ought to receive such: that we may be fellow helpers of the truth.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I had written perhaps to the church: but Diotrephes, who loveth to have the preeminence among them, doth not receive us.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For this cause, if I come, I will advertise his works which he doth, with malicious words prating against us. And as if these things were not enough for him, neither doth he himself receive the brethren, and them that do receive them he forbiddeth, and casteth out of the church. Diotrephes who loveth.... This man seemeth to be in power, but not a friend to the faithful; therefore this part of the letter might be an admonition to him from the apostle.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, follow not that which is evil: but that which is good. He that doth good is of God: he that doth evil hath not seen God.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: To Demetrius, testimony is given by all, and by the truth itself: yea and we also give testimony. And thou knowest that our testimony is true.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I had many things to write unto thee: but I would not by ink and pen write to thee.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But I hope speedily to see thee: and we will speak mouth to mouth. Peace be to thee. Our friends salute thee. Salute the friends by name. THE CATHOLIC EPISTLE OF ST. JUDE St. Jude, who wrote this Epistle, was one of the twelve Apostles and brother to St. James the Less. The time it was written is uncertain: only it may be inferred from verse 17 that few or none of the Apostles were then living, except St. John. He inveighs against the heresies and wicked practices of the Simonians, Nicolaites, and Gnostics, etc., describing them and their leaders by strong epithets and similes, He exhorts the faithful to contend earnestly for the faith first delivered to them and to beware of heretics. Jude Chapter 1 He exhorts them to stand to the faith first delivered to them and to beware of heretics.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Jude, the servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James: to them that are beloved in God the Father and preserved in Jesus Christ and called.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Mercy unto you and peace: and charity be fulfilled.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, taking all care to write unto you concerning your common salvation, I was under a necessity to write unto you: to beseech you to contend earnestly for the faith once delivered to the saints.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For certain men are secretly entered in (who were written of long ago unto this judgment), ungodly men, turning the grace of our Lord God into riotousness and denying the only sovereign Ruler and our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I will therefore admonish you, though ye once knew all things, that Jesus, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, did afterwards destroy them that believed not.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And the angels who kept not their principality but forsook their own habitation, he hath reserved under darkness in everlasting chains, unto the judgment of the great day. Principality.... That is, the state in which they were first created, their original dignity.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: As Sodom and Gomorrha and the neighbouring cities, in like manner, having given themselves to fornication and going after other flesh, were made an example, suffering the punishment of eternal fire.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In like manner, these men also defile the flesh and despise dominion and blaspheme majesty. Blaspheme majesty.... Speak evil of them that are in dignity; and even utter blasphemies against the divine majesty.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: When Michael the archangel, disputing with the devil, contended about the body of Moses, he durst not bring against him the judgment of railing speech, but said: The Lord command thee. Contended about the body, etc.... This contention, which is no where else mentioned in holy writ, was originally known by revelation, and transmitted by tradition. It is thought the occasion of it was, that the devil would have had the body buried in such a place and manner, as to be worshipped by the Jews with divine honours. Command thee.... or rebuke thee.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But these men blaspheme whatever things they know not: and what things soever they naturally know, like dumb beasts, in these they are corrupted.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Woe unto them! For they have gone in the way of Cain: and after the error of Balaam they have for reward poured out themselves and have perished in the contradiction of Core. Gone in the way, etc.... Heretics follow the way of Cain, by murdering the souls of their brethren; the way of Balaam, by putting a scandal before the people of God, for their own private ends; and the way of Core or Korah, by their opposition to the church governors of divine appointment.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: These are spots in their banquets, feasting together without fear, feeding themselves: clouds without water, which are carried about by winds: trees of the autumn, unfruitful, twice dead, plucked up by the roots:

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Raging waves of the sea, foaming out their own confusion: wandering stars, to whom the storm of darkness is reserved for ever.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Now of these Enoch also, the seventh from Adam, prophesied, saying: Behold, the Lord cometh with thousands of his saints: Prophesied.... This prophecy was either known by tradition, or from some book that is since lost.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: To execute judgment upon all and to reprove all the ungodly for all the works of their ungodliness, whereby they have done ungodly: and for all the hard things which ungodly sinners have spoken against God.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: These are murmurers, full of complaints, walking according to their own desires: and their mouth speaketh proud things, admiring persons, for gain’s sake.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But you, my dearly beloved, be mindful of the words which have been spoken before by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ: But you, my dearly beloved, be mindful, etc.... He now exhorts the faithful to remain steadfast in the belief and practice of what they had heard from the apostles, who had also foretold that in aftertimes (lit. in the last time) there should be false teachers, scoffing and ridiculing all revealed truths, abandoning themselves to their passions and lusts; who separate themselves from the Catholic communion by heresies and schisms. Sensual men.... carried away and enslaved by the pleasures of the senses.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Who told you that in the last time there should come mockers, walking according to their own desires in ungodlinesses.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: These are they who separate themselves, sensual men, having not the Spirit.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But you, my beloved, building yourselves upon your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost,

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Keep yourselves in the love of God, waiting for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, unto life everlasting. Building yourselves upon your most holy faith.... Raising by your actions, a spiritual building, founded, 1st, upon faith; 2d, on the love of God; 3d, upon hope, whilst you are waiting for the mercies of God, and the reward of eternal life; 4th, joined with the great duty of prayer.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And some indeed reprove, being judged:

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But others save, pulling them out of the fire. And on others have mercy, in fear, hating also the spotted garment which is carnal. And some indeed reprove being judged.... He gives them another instruction to practice charity in endeavouring to convert their neighbour, where they will meet with three sorts of persons: 1st, With persons obstinate in their errors and sins; these may be said to be already judged and condemned; they are to be sharply reprehended, reproved, and if possible convinced of their error. 2d, As to others you must endeavour to save them, by pulling them, as it were, out of the fire, from the ruin they stand in great danger of. 3d, You must have mercy on others in fear, when you see them through ignorance of frailty, in danger of being drawn into the snares of these heretics; with these you must deal more gently and mildly, with a charitable compassion, hating always, and teaching others to hate the carnal garment which is spotted, their sensual and corrupt manners, that defile both the soul and body.

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Now to him who is able to preserve you without sin and to present you spotless before the presence of his glory with exceeding joy, in the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ:

Book: The Third Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: To the only God our Saviour through Jesus Christ our Lord, be glory and magnificence, empire and power, before all ages, and now, and for all ages of ages. Amen. Now to him, etc.... St. Jude concludes his epistle with this doxology of praising God, and praying to the only God our Saviour, which may either signify God the Father, or God as equally agreeing to all the three persons, who are equally the cause of Christ’s incarnation, and man’s salvation, through Jesus Christ our Lord, who, being God from eternity, took upon him our human nature, that he might become our Redeemer.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Paul, a prisoner of Christ Jesus, and Timothy, a brother: to Philemon, our beloved and fellow labourer,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: And to Appia, our dearest sister, and to Archippus, our fellow soldier, and to the church which is in thy house.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Grace to you and peace, from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: I give thanks to my God, always making a remembrance of thee in my prayers.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Hearing of thy charity and faith, which thou hast in the Lord Jesus and towards all the saints:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: That the communication of thy faith may be made evident in the acknowledgment of every good work that is in you in Christ Jesus.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: For I have had great joy and consolation in thy charity, because the bowels of the saints have been refreshed by thee, brother.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Wherefore, though I have much confidence in Christ Jesus to command thee that which is to the purpose:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: For charity sake I rather beseech, whereas thou art such a one, as Paul, an old man and now a prisoner also of Jesus Christ.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: I beseech thee for my son, whom I have begotten in my bands, Onesimus,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Who hath been heretofore unprofitable to thee but now is profitable both to me and thee:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Whom I have sent back to thee. And do thou receive him as my own bowels.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Whom I would have retained with me, that in thy stead he might have ministered to me in the bands of the gospel.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: But without thy counsel I would do nothing: that thy good deed might not be as it were of necessity, but voluntary.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: For perhaps he therefore departed for a season from thee that thou mightest receive him again for ever:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Not now as a servant, but instead of a servant, a most dear brother, especially to me. But how much more to thee, both in the flesh and in the Lord?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: If therefore thou count me a partner, receive him as myself.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: And if he hath wronged thee in any thing or is in thy debt, put that to my account.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: I Paul have written it with my own hand: I will repay it: not to say to thee that thou owest me thy own self also.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Yea, brother. May I enjoy thee in the Lord! Refresh my bowels in the Lord.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Trusting in thy obedience, I have written to thee: knowing that thou wilt also do more than I say.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: But withal prepare me also a lodging. For I hope that through your prayers I shall be given unto you.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: There salute thee Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: Mark, Aristarchus, Demas and Luke, my fellow labourers.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to Philemon
Text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: God, who, at sundry times and in divers manners, spoke in times past to the fathers by the prophets, last of all,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: In these days, hath spoken to us by his Son, whom he hath appointed heir of all things, by whom also he made the world.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who being the brightness of his glory and the figure of his substance and upholding all things by the word of his power, making purgation of sins, sitteth on the right hand of the majesty on high: The figure ... that is, the express image, and most perfect resemblance. Making purgation.... That is, having purged away our sins by his passion.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Being made so much better than the angels as he hath inherited a more excellent name than they.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For to which of the angels hath he said at any time: Thou art my Son, to-day have I begotten thee? And again: I will be to him a Father, and he shall be to me a Son?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And again, when he bringeth in the first begotten into the world, he saith: And let all the angels of God adore him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And to the angels indeed he saith: He that maketh his angels spirits and his ministers a flame of fire.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But to the Son: Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever: a sceptre of justice is the sceptre of thy kingdom.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Thou hast loved justice and hated iniquity: therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And: Thou in the beginning, O Lord, didst found the earth: and the works of thy hands are the heavens.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: They shall perish: but thou shalt continue: and they shall all grow old as a garment.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And as a vesture shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed. But thou art the selfsame: and thy years shall not fail.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But to which of the angels said he at any time: Sit on my right hand, until I make thy enemies thy footstool?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Are they not all ministering spirits, sent to minister for them who shall receive the inheritance of salvation? Hebrews Chapter 2 The transgression of the precepts of the Son of God is far more condemnable than of those of the Old Testament given by angels.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Therefore ought we more diligently to observe the things which we have heard lest perhaps we should let them slip.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For if the word spoken by angels became steadfast and every transgression and disobedience received a just recompense of reward:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: How shall we escape if we neglect so great salvation? Which, having begun to be declared by the Lord, was confirmed unto us by them that heard him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: God also bearing them witness by signs and wonders and divers miracles and distributions of the Holy Ghost, according to his own will.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For God hath not subjected unto angels the world to come, whereof we speak.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But one in a certain place hath testified, saying: What is man, that thou art mindful of him? Or the son of man, that thou visitest him?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Thou hast made him a little lower than the angels: thou hast crowned him with glory and honour and hast set him over the works of thy hands.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Thou hast subjected all things under his feet. For in that he hath subjected all things to him he left nothing not subject to him. But now we see not as yet all things subject to him.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But we see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels, for the suffering of death, crowned with glory and honour: that, through the grace of God he might taste death for all.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For it became him for whom are all things and by whom are all things, who had brought many children into glory, to perfect the author of their salvation, by his passion. Perfect by his passion.... By suffering, Christ was to enter into his glory, Luke 24.26, which the apostle here calls being made perfect.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For both he that sanctifieth and they who are sanctified are all of one. For which cause he is not ashamed to call them brethren, saying:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: I will declare thy name to my brethren: in the midst of the church will I praise thee.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And again: I will put my trust in him. And again: Behold I and my children, whom God hath given me.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Therefore because the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself in like manner hath been partaker of the same: that, through death, he might destroy him who had the empire of death, that is to say, the devil:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And might deliver them, who through the fear of death were all their lifetime subject to servitude.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For nowhere doth he take hold of the angels: but of the seed of Abraham he taketh hold. No where doth he, etc.... That is, he never took upon him the nature of angels, but that of the seed of Abraham.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore, it behoved him in all things to be made like unto his brethren, that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest before God, that he might be a propitiation for the sins of the people.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For in that wherein he himself hath suffered and been tempted he is able to succour them also that are tempted. Hebrews Chapter 3 Christ is more excellent than Moses. Wherefore we must adhere to him by faith and obedience.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore, holy brethren, partakers of the heavenly vocation consider the apostle and high priest of our confession, Jesus:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Who is faithful to him that made him, as was also Moses in all his house.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For this man was counted worthy of greater glory than Moses, by so much as he that hath built the house hath greater honour than the house.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For every house is built by some man: but he that created all things is God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And Moses indeed was faithful in all his house as a servant, for a testimony of those things which were to be said:

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But Christ, as the Son in his own house: which house are we, if we hold fast the confidence and glory of hope unto the end.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Wherefore, as the Holy Ghost saith: To-day if you shall hear his voice,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the desert,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Where your fathers tempted me, proved and saw my works,

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Forty years: for which cause I was offended with this generation, and I said: They always err in heart. And they have not known my ways.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: As I have sworn in my wrath: If they shall enter into my rest.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: Take heed, brethren, lest perhaps there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, to depart from the living God.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: But exhort one another every day, whilst it is called to day, that none of you be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For we are made partakers of Christ: yet so, if we hold the beginning of his substance firm unto the end.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: While it is said: To day, if you shall hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in that provocation.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: For some who heard did provoke: but not all that came out of Egypt by Moses.

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And with whom was he offended forty years? Was it not with them that sinned, whose carcasses were overthrown in the desert?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
Text: And to whom did he swear, that they should not enter into his rest: but to them that were incredulous?

Book: The Epistle of St. Paul to the Hebrews
