Text: And the scripture was fulfilled, saying: Abraham believed God, and it was reputed to him to justice, and he was called the friend of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Do you see that by works a man is justified, and not by faith only?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And in like manner also Rahab the harlot, was not she justified by works, receiving the messengers and sending them out another way?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For even as the body without the spirit is dead: so also faith without works is dead. James Chapter 3 Of the evils of the tongue. Of the difference between the earthly and heavenly wisdom.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be ye not many masters, my brethren, knowing that you receive the greater judgment.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For in many things we all offend. If any man offend not in word, the same is a perfect man. He is able also with a bridle to lead about the whole body.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For if we put bits into the mouths of horses, that they may obey us: and we turn about their whole body.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold also ships, whereas they are great and are driven by strong winds, yet are they turned about with a small helm, whithersoever the force of the governor willeth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Even so the tongue is indeed a little member and boasteth great things. Behold how small a fire kindleth a great wood.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity. The tongue is placed among our members, which defileth the whole body and inflameth the wheel of our nativity, being set on fire by hell.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For every nature of beasts and of birds and of serpents and of the rest is tamed and hath been tamed, by the nature of man.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But the tongue no man can tame, an unquiet evil, full of deadly poison.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: By it we bless God and the Father: and by it we curse men who are made after the likeness of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Out of the same mouth proceedeth blessing and cursing. My brethren, these things ought not so to be.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Doth a fountain send forth, out of the same hole, sweet and bitter water?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear grapes? Or the vine, figs? So neither can the salt water yield sweet.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Who is a wise man and endued with knowledge, among you? Let him shew, by a good conversation, his work in the meekness of wisdom.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But if you have bitter zeal, and there be contentions in your hearts: glory not and be not liars against the truth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For this is not wisdom, descending from above: but earthly, sensual, devilish.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For where envying and contention is: there is inconstancy and every evil work.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But the wisdom that is from above, first indeed is chaste, then peaceable, modest, easy to be persuaded, consenting to the good, full of mercy and good fruits, without judging, without dissimulation.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the fruit of justice is sown in peace, to them that make peace. James Chapter 4 The evils that flow from yielding to concupiscence and being friends to this world. Admonitions against pride, detraction and the like.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: From whence are wars and contentions among you? Are they not hence, from your concupiscences, which war in your members?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You covet, and have not: you kill and envy and cannot obtain. You contend and war, and you have not: because you ask not.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You ask and receive not: because you ask amiss, that you may consume it on your concupiscences.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Adulterers, know you not that the friendship of this world is the enemy of God? Whosoever therefore will be a friend of this world becometh an enemy of God.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Or do you think that the scripture saith in vain: To envy doth the spirit covet which dwelleth in you?

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But he giveth greater grace. Wherefore he saith: God resisteth the proud and giveth grace to the humble.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be subject therefore to God. But resist the devil: and he will fly from you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Draw nigh to God: and he will draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye sinners, and purify your hearts, ye double minded.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be afflicted and mourn and weep: let your laughter be turned into mourning and your joy into sorrow.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be humbled in the sight of the Lord: and he will exalt you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Detract not one another, my brethren. He that detracteth his brother, or he that judgeth his brother, detracteth the law and judgeth the law. But if thou judge the law, thou art not a doer of the law, but a judge.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: There is one lawgiver and judge, that is able to destroy and to deliver.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But who art thou that judgest thy neighbour? Behold, now you that say: To-day or to-morrow we will go into such a city, and there we will spend a year and will traffic and make our gain.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Whereas you know not what shall be on the morrow.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: For what is your life? It is a vapour which appeareth for a little while and afterwards shall vanish away. For that you should say: If the Lord will, and, If we shall live, we will do this or that.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But now you rejoice in your arrogancies. All such rejoicing is wicked.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: To him therefore who knoweth to do good and doth it not, to him it is sin. James Chapter 5 A woe to the rich that oppress the poor. Exhortations to patience and to avoid swearing. Of the anointing the sick, confession of sins and fervour in prayer.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Go to now, ye rich men: weep and howl in your miseries, which shall come upon you.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Your riches are corrupted: and your garments are motheaten.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Your gold and silver is cankered: and the rust of them shall be for a testimony against you and shall eat your flesh like fire. You have stored up to yourselves wrath against the last days.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold the hire of the labourers who have reaped down your fields, which by fraud has been kept back by you, crieth: and the cry of them hath entered into the ears of the Lord of Sabaoth.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You have feasted upon earth: and in riotousness you have nourished your hearts, in the day of slaughter.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: You have condemned and put to death the Just One: and he resisted you not.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be patient therefore, brethren, until the coming of the Lord. Behold, the husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the earth: patiently bearing till he receive the early and latter rain.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Be you therefore also patient and strengthen your hearts: for the coming of the Lord is at hand.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Grudge not, brethren, one against another, that you may not be judged. Behold the judge standeth before the door.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Take, my brethren, for an example of suffering evil, of labour and patience, the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Behold, we account them blessed who have endured. You have heard of the patience of Job and you have seen the end of the Lord, that the Lord is merciful and compassionate.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: But above all things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, nor by the earth, nor by any other oath. But let your speech be: Yea, Yea: No, No: that you fall not under judgment.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Is any of you sad? Let him pray: Is he cheerful in mind? Let him sing.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Is any man sick among you? Let him bring in the priests of the church and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord. Let him bring in, etc.... See here a plain warrant of scripture for the sacrament of extreme unction, that any controversy against its institution would be against the express words of the sacred text in the plainest terms.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And the prayer of faith shall save the sick man. And the Lord shall raise him up: and if he be in sins, they shall be forgiven him.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Confess therefore your sins one to another: and pray one for another, that you may be saved. For the continual prayer of a just man availeth much. Confess your sins one to another.... That is, to the priests of the church, whom (ver.14) he had ordered to be called for, and brought in to the sick; moreover, to confess to persons who had no power to forgive sins, would be useless. Hence the precept here means, that we must confess to men whom God hath appointed, and who, by their ordination and jurisdiction, have received the power of remitting sins in his name.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: Elias was a man passible like unto us: and with prayer he prayed that it might not rain upon the earth. And it rained not for three years and six months.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: And he prayed again. And the heaven gave rain: and the earth brought forth her fruit.

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: My brethren, if any of you err from the truth and one convert him:

Book: The Catholic Epistle of St. James the Apostle
Text: He must know that he who causeth a sinner to be converted from the error of his way shall save his soul from death and shall cover a multitude of sins.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes, which we have looked upon and our hands have handled, of the word of life.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For the life was manifested: and we have seen and do bear witness and declare unto you the life eternal, which was with the Father and hath appeared to us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: That which we have seen and have heard, we declare unto you: that you also may have fellowship with us and our fellowship may be with the Father and with his Son Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And these things we write to you, that you may rejoice and your joy may be full.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is the declaration which we have heard from him and declare unto you: That God is light and in him there is no darkness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If we say that we have fellowship with him and walk in darkness, we lie and do not the truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But if we walk in the light, as he also is in the light, we have fellowship one with another: And the blood of Jesus Christ his Son cleanseth us from all sin.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all iniquity.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If we say that we have not sinned, we make him a liar: and his word is not in us. 1 John Chapter 2 Christ is our advocate. We must keep his commandments and love one another. We must not love the world nor give ear to new teachers, but abide by the spirit of God in the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: My little children, these things I write to you, that you may not sin. But if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the just.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And he is the propitiation for our sins: and not for ours only, but also for those of the whole world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And by this we know that we have known him, if we keep his commandments. We have known him, if we keep his commandments.... He speaks of that practical knowledge by love and affection, which can only be proved by our keeping his commandments; and without which we can not be said to know God as we should do.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He who saith that he knoweth him and keepeth not his commandments is a liar: and the truth is not in him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But he that keepeth his word, in him in very deed the charity of God is perfected. And by this we know that we are in him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that saith he abideth in him ought himself also to walk even as he walked.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, I write not a new commandment to you, but an old commandment which you had from the beginning. The old commandment is the word which you have heard.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Again a new commandment I write unto you: which thing is true both in him and in you, because the darkness is passed and the true light now shineth. A new commandment.... Viz., the commandment of love, which was first given in the old law; but was renewed and extended by Christ. See John 13.34.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that saith he is in the light and hateth his brother is in darkness even until now.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that loveth his brother abideth in the light: and there is no scandal in him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But he that hateth his brother is in darkness and walketh in darkness and knoweth not whither he goeth: because the darkness hath blinded his eyes.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I write unto you, little children, because your sins are forgiven you for his name’s sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I write unto you, fathers, because you have known him who is from the beginning. I write unto you, young men, because you have overcome the wicked one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I write unto you, babes, because you have known the Father. I write unto you, young men, because you are strong, and the word of God abideth in you, and you have overcome the wicked one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Love not the world, nor the things which are in the world. If any man love the world, the charity of the Father is not in him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For all that is in the world is the concupiscence of the flesh and the concupiscence of the eyes and the pride of life, which is not of the Father but is of the world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And the world passeth away and the concupiscence thereof: but he that doth the will of God abideth for ever.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Little children, it is the last hour: and as you have heard that Antichrist cometh, even now there are become many Antichrists: whereby we know that it is the last hour. It is the last hour.... That is, it is the last age of the world. Many Antichrists; ... that is, many heretics, enemies of Christ and his church, and forerunners of the great Antichrist.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: They went out from us but they were not of us. For if they had been of us, they would no doubt have remained with us: but that they may be manifest, that they are not all of us. They were not of us.... That is, they were not solid, steadfast, genuine Christians: otherwise they would have remained in the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: But you have the unction from the Holy One and know all things. The unction from the Holy One.... That is, grace and wisdom from the Holy Ghost. Know all things.... The true children of God’s church, remaining in unity, under the guidance of their lawful pastors, partake of the grace of the Holy Ghost, promised to the church and her pastors; and have in the church all necessary knowledge and instruction; so as to have no need to seek it elsewhere, since it can be only found in that society of which they are members.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I have not written to you as to them that know not the truth, but as to them that know it: and that no lie is of the truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Who is a liar, but he who denieth that Jesus is the Christ? This is Antichrist, who denieth the Father and the Son.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever denieth the Son, the same hath not the Father. He that confesseth the Son hath the Father also.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: As for you, let that which you have heard from the beginning abide in you. If that abide in you, which you have heard from the beginning, you also shall abide in the Son and in the Father.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is the promise which he hath promised us, life everlasting.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: These things have I written to you concerning them that seduce you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And as for you, let the unction, which you have received from him abide in you. And you have no need that any man teach you: but as his unction teacheth you of all things and is truth and is no lie. And as it hath taught you, abide in him. You have no need, etc.... You want not to be taught by any of these men, who, under pretence of imparting more knowledge to you, seek to seduce you (ver. 26), since you are sufficiently taught already, and have all knowledge and grace in the church, with the unction of the Holy Ghost; which these new teachers have no share in.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And now, little children, abide in him, that when he shall appear we may have confidence and not be confounded by him at his coming.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If you know that he is just, know ye, that every one also who doth justice is born of him. 1 John Chapter 3 Of the love of God to us. How we may distinguish the children of God and those of the devil. Of loving one another and of purity of conscience.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Behold what manner of charity the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called and should be the sons of God. Therefore the world knoweth not us, because it knew not him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, we are now the sons of God: and it hath not yet appeared what we shall be. We know that when he shall appear we shall be like to him: because we shall see him as he is.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And every one that hath this hope in him sanctifieth himself, as he also is holy.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever committeth sin committeth also iniquity. And sin is iniquity. Iniquity.... transgression of the law.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And you know that he appeared to take away our sins: and in him there is no sin.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever abideth in him sinneth not: and whosoever sinneth hath not seen him nor known him. Sinneth not.... viz., mortally. See chap. 1.8.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Little children, let no man deceive you. He that doth justice is just, even as he is just.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that committeth sin is of the devil: for the devil sinneth from the beginning. For this purpose the Son of God appeared, that he might destroy the works of the devil.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever is born of God committeth not sin: for his seed abideth in him. And he cannot sin, because he is born of God. Committeth not sin.... That is, as long as he keepeth in himself this seed of grace, and this divine generation, by which he is born of God. But then he may fall from this happy state, by the abuse of his free will, as appears from Rom. 11.20-22; Cor. 9.27; and 10.12; Phil. 2.12; Apoc. 3.11.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this the children of God are manifest, and the children of the devil. Whosoever is not just is not of God, nor he that loveth not his brother.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For this is the declaration which you have heard from the beginning, that you should love one another.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Not as Cain, who was of the wicked one and killed his brother. And wherefore did he kill him? Because his own works were wicked: and his brother’s just.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Wonder not, brethren, if the world hate you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: We know that we have passed from death to life, because we love the brethren. He that loveth not abideth in death.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer. And you know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in himself.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this we have known the charity of God, because he hath laid down his life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath the substance of this world and shall see his brother in need and shall shut up his bowels from him: how doth the charity of God abide in him?

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: My little children, let us not love in word nor in tongue, but in deed and in truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this we know that we are of the truth and in his sight shall persuade our hearts.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For if our heart reprehend us, God is greater than our heart and knoweth all things.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, if our heart do not reprehend us, we have confidence towards God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And whatsoever we shall ask, we shall receive of him: because we keep his commandments and do those things which are pleasing in his sight.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is his commandment: That we should believe in the name of his Son Jesus Christ and love one another, as he hath given commandment unto us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And he that keepeth his commandments abideth in him, and he in him. And in this we know that he abideth in us by the Spirit which he hath given us. 1 John Chapter 4 What spirits are of God, and what are not. We must love one another, because God has loved us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits if they be of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world. Try the spirits.... Viz., by examining whether their teaching be agreeable to the rule of the Catholic faith, and the doctrine of the church. For as he says, (ver. 6,) He that knoweth God, heareth us [the pastors of the church]. By this we know the spirit of truth, and the spirit of error.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: By this is the spirit of God known. Every spirit which confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is of God: Every spirit which confesseth, etc.... Not that the confession of this point of faith alone, is, at all times, and in all cases, sufficient; but that with relation to that time, and for that part of the Christian doctrine, which was then particularly to be confessed, taught, and maintained against the heretics of those days, this was the most proper token, by which the true teachers might be distinguished form the false.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And every spirit that dissolveth Jesus is not of God. And this is Antichrist, of whom you have heard that he cometh: and he is now already in the world. That dissolveth Jesus.... Viz., either by denying his humanity, or his divinity. He is now already in the world.... Not in his person, but in his spirit, and in his precursors.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: You are of God, little children, and have overcome him. Because greater is he that is in you, than he that is in the world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: They are of the world. Therefore of the world they speak: and the world heareth them.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: We are of God. He that knoweth God heareth us. He that is not of God heareth us not. By this we know the spirit of truth and the spirit of error.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Dearly beloved, let us love one another: for charity is of God. And every one that loveth is born of God and knoweth God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that loveth not knoweth not God: for God is charity.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: By this hath the charity of God appeared towards us, because God hath sent his only begotten Son into the world, that we may live by him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this is charity: not as though we had loved God, but because he hath first loved us, and sent his Son to be a propitiation for our sins.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: My dearest, if God hath so loved us, we also ought to love one another.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: No man hath seen God at any time. If we love one another, God abideth in us: and his charity is perfected in us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this we know that we abide in him, and he in us: because he hath given us of his spirit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And we have seen and do testify that the Father hath sent his Son to be the Saviour of the world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God abideth in him, and he in God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And we have known and have believed the charity which God hath to us. God is charity: and he that abideth in charity abideth in God, and God in him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this is the charity of God perfected with us, that we may have confidence in the day of judgment: because as he is, we also are in this world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Fear is not in charity: but perfect charity casteth out fear, because fear hath pain. And he that feareth is not perfected in charity. Fear is not in charity, etc.... Perfect charity, or love, banisheth human fear, that is, the fear of men; as also all perplexing fear, which makes men mistrust or despair of God’s mercy; and that kind of servile fear, which makes them fear the punishment of sin more than the offence offered to God. But it no way excludes the wholesome fear of God’s judgments, so often recomended in holy writ; nor that fear and trembling, with which we are told to work out our salvation. Phil. 2.12.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Let us therefore love God: because God first hath loved us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If any man say: I love God, and hateth his brother; he is a liar. For he that loveth not his brother whom he seeth, how can he love God whom he seeth not?

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this commandment we have from God, that he who loveth God love also his brother. 1 John Chapter 5 Of them that are born of God, and of true charity. Faith overcomes the world. Three that bear witness to Christ. Of faith in his name and of sin that is and is not to death.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever believeth that Jesus is the Christ, is born of God. And every one that loveth him who begot, loveth him also who is born of him. Is born of God.... That is, is justified, and become a child of God by baptism: which is also to be understood; provided the belief of this fundamental article of the Christian faith be accompanied with all the other conditions, which, by the word of God, and his appointment, are also required to justification; such as a general belief of all that God has revealed and promised: hope, love, repentance, and a sincere disposition to keep God’s holy law and commandments.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: In this we know that we love the children of God: when we love God and keep his commandments.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For this is the charity of God: That we keep his commandments. And his commandments are not heavy.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For whatsoever is born of God overcometh the world. And this is the victory which overcometh the world: Our faith. Our faith.... Not a bare, speculative, or dead faith; but a faith that worketh by charity. Gal. 5.6

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Who is he that overcometh the world, but he that believeth that Jesus is the Son of God?

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: This is he that came by water and blood, Jesus Christ: not by water only but by water and blood. And it is the Spirit which testifieth that Christ is the truth. Came by water and blood.... Not only to wash away our sins by the water of baptism, but by his own blood.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And there are Three who give testimony in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost. And these three are one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And there are three that give testimony on earth: the spirit and the water and the blood. And these three are one. The spirit, and the water, and the blood.... As the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost, all bear witness to Christ’s divinity; so the spirit, which he yielded up, crying out with a loud voice upon the cross; and the water and blood that issued from his side, bear witness to his humanity, and are one; that is, all agree in one testimony.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If we receive the testimony of men, the testimony of God is greater. For this is the testimony of God, which is greater, because he hath testified of his Son.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that believeth in the Son of God hath the testimony of God in himself. He that believeth not the Son maketh him a liar: because he believeth not in the testimony which God hath testified of his Son. He that believeth not the Son, etc.... By refusing to believe the testimonies given by the three divine persons, that Jesus was the Messias, and the true Son of God, by whom eternal life is obtained and promised to all that comply with his doctrine. In him we have also this lively confidence, that we shall obtain whatever we ask, according to his will, when we ask what is for our good, with perseverance, and in the manner we ought. And this we know, and have experience of, by having obtained the petitions that we have made.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is the testimony that God hath given to us eternal life. And this life is in his Son.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that hath the Son hath life. He that hath not the Son hath not life.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: These things I write to you that you may know that you have eternal life: you who believe in the name of the Son of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is the confidence which we have towards him: That, whatsoever we shall ask according to his will, he heareth us.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And we know that he heareth us whatsoever we ask: we know that we have the petitions which we request of him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: He that knoweth his brother to sin a sin which is not to death, let him ask: and life shall be given to him who sinneth not to death. There is a sin unto death. For that I say not that any man ask. A sin which is not to death, etc.... It is hard to determine what St. John here calls a sin which is not to death, and a sin which is unto death. The difference can not be the same as betwixt sins that are called venial and mortal: for he says, that if a man pray for his brother, who commits a sin that is not to death, life shall be given him: therefore such a one had before lost the life of grace, and been guilty of what is commonly called a mortal sin. And when he speaks of a sin that is unto death, and adds these words, for that I say not that any man ask, it cannot be supposed that St. John would say this of every mortal sin, but only of some heinous sins, which are very seldom remitted, because such sinners very seldom repent. By a sin therefore which is unto death, interpreters commonly understand a wilfull apostasy from the faith, and from the known truth, when a sinner, hardened by his own ingratitude, becomes deaf to all admonitions, will do nothing for himself, but runs on to a final impenitence. Nor yet does St. John say, that such a sin is never remitted, or cannot be remitted, but only has these words, for that I say not that any man ask the remission: that is, though we must pray for all sinners whatsoever, yet men can not pray for such sinners with such a confidence of obtaining always their petitions, as St. John said before, ver. 14. Whatever exposition we follow on this verse, our faith teacheth us from the holy scriptures, that God desires not the death of any sinner, but that he be converted and live, Ezech. 33.11. Though men’s sins be as red as scarlet, they shall become as white as snow, Isa. 3.18. It is the will of God that every one come to the knowledge of the truth, and be saved. There is no sin so great but which God is willing to forgive, and has left a power in his church to remit the most enormous sins: so that no sinner need despair of pardon, nor will any sinner perish, but by his own fault. A sin unto death.... Some understand this of final impenitence, or of dying in mortal sin; which is the only sin that never can be remitted. But, it is probable, he may also comprise under this name, the sin of apostasy from the faith, and some other such heinous sins as are seldom and hardly remitted: and therefore he gives little encouragement, to such as pray for these sinners, to expect what they ask.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: All iniquity is sin. And there is a sin unto death.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: We know that whosoever is born of God sinneth not: but the generation of God preserveth him and the wicked one toucheth him not.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: We know that we are of God and the whole world is seated in wickedness. And the whole world is seated in wickedness.... That is, a great part of the world. It may also signify, is under the wicked one, meaning the devil, who is elsewhere called the prince of this world, that is, of all the wicked. John 12.31.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And we know that the Son of God is come. And he hath given us understanding that we may know the true God and may be in his true Son. This is the true God and life eternal. And may be in his true Son. He is, or this is the true God, and life eternal.... Which words are a clear proof of Christ’s divinity, and as such made use of by the ancient fathers.

Book: The First Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Little children, keep yourselves from idols. Amen. Keep yourselves from idols.... An admonition to the newly converted Christians, lest conversing with heathens and idolaters, they might fall back into the sin of idolatry, which may be the sin unto death here mentioned by St. John.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: The Ancient to the lady Elect and her children, whom I love in the truth: and not I only, but also all they that have known the truth, The ancient.... That is, the ancient bishop St. John, being the only one of the twelve apostles then living. To the lady Elect.... Some conjecture that Electa might be the name of a family, or of a particular church; but the general opinion is, that it is the proper name of a lady, so eminent for her piety and great charity, as to merit this Epistle from St. John.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For the sake of the truth which dwelleth in us and shall be with us for ever.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Grace be with you, mercy and peace from God the Father and from Christ Jesus the Son of the Father: in truth and charity.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: I was exceeding glad that I found of thy children walking in truth, as we have received a commandment from the Father.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And now I beseech thee, lady, not as writing a new commandment to thee, but that which we have had from the beginning, that we love one another.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: And this is charity: That we walk according to his commandments. For this is the commandment that, as you have heard from the beginning, you should walk in the same:

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For many seducers are gone out into the world who confess not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh. This is a seducer and an antichrist.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Look to yourselves, that you lose not the things which you have wrought: but that you may receive a full reward.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Whosoever revolteth and continueth not in the doctrine of Christ hath not God. He that continueth in the doctrine, the same hath both the Father and the Son.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: If any man come to you and bring not this doctrine, receive him not into the house nor say to him: God speed you. Nor say to him, God speed you.... This admonition is in general, to forewarn the faithful of the dangers which may arise from a familiarity with those who have prevaricated and gone from the true faith, and with such as teach false doctrine. But this is not forbidding a charity for all men, by which we ought to wish and pray for the eternal salvation of every one, even of our enemies.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: For he that saith unto him: God speed you, communicateth with his wicked works.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: Having more things to write unto you, I would not by paper and ink: for I hope that I shall be with you and speak face to face, that your joy may be full.

Book: The Second Epistle of St. John the Apostle
Text: The children of thy sister Elect salute thee.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Paul, called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Sosthenes a brother,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To the church of God that is at Corinth, to them that are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be saints, with all that invoke the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place of theirs and ours.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Grace to you and peace, from God our father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I give thanks to my God always for you, for the grace of God that is given you in Christ Jesus:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That in all things you are made rich in him, in all utterance and in all knowledge;

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As the testimony of Christ was confirmed in you,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So that nothing is wanting to you in any grace, waiting for the manifestation of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who also will confirm you unto the end without crime, in the day of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: God is faithful: by whom you are called unto the fellowship of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I beseech you, brethren, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you all speak the same thing and that there be no schisms among you: but that you be perfect in the same mind and in the same judgment.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it hath been signified unto me, my brethren, of you, by them that are of the house of Chloe, that there are contentions among you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I say, that every one of you saith: I indeed am of Paul; and I am of Apollo; and I of Cephas; and I of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Is Christ divided? Was Paul then crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I give God thanks, that I baptized none of you but Crispus and Caius:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Lest any should say that you were baptized in my name.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I baptized also the household of Stephanus. Besides, I know not whether I baptized any other.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the gospel: not in wisdom of speech, lest the cross of Christ should be made void.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the word of the cross, to them indeed that perish, is foolishness: but to them that are saved, that is, to us, it is the power of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it is written: I will destroy the wisdom of the wise: and the prudence of the prudent I will reject.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the disputer of this world? Hath not God made foolish the wisdom of this world?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For, seeing that in the wisdom of God, the world, by wisdom, knew not God, it pleased God, by the foolishness of our preaching, to save them that believe.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For both the Jews require signs: and the Greeks seek after wisdom.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we preach Christ crucified: unto the Jews indeed a stumblingblock, and unto the Gentiles foolishness:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But unto them that are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ, the power of God and the wisdom of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the foolishness of God is wiser than men: and the weakness of God is stronger than men. The foolishness, etc.... That is to say, what appears foolish to the world in the ways of God, is indeed most wise; and what appears weak is indeed above all the strength and comprehension of man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For see your vocation, brethren, that there are not many wise according to the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the foolish things of the world hath God chosen, that he may confound the wise: and the weak things of the world hath God chosen, that he may confound the strong.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the base things of the world and the things that are contemptible, hath God chosen: and things that are not, that he might bring to nought things that are:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That no flesh should glory in his sight.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But of him are you in Christ Jesus, who of God is made unto us wisdom and justice and sanctification and redemption:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That, as it is written: He that glorieth may glory in the Lord. 1 Corinthians Chapter 2 His preaching was not in loftiness of words, but in spirit and power. And the wisdom he taught was not to be understood by the worldly wise or sensual man, but only by the spiritual man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I, brethren, when I came to you, came not in loftiness of speech or of wisdom, declaring unto you the testimony of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I judged not myself to know anything among you, but Jesus Christ: and him crucified.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I was with you in weakness and in fear and in much trembling.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And my speech and my preaching was not in the persuasive words of human wisdom, but in shewing of the Spirit and power:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That your faith might not stand on the wisdom of men, but on the power of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Howbeit we speak wisdom among the perfect: yet not the wisdom of this world, neither of the princes of this world that come to nought.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, a wisdom which is hidden, which God ordained before the world, unto our glory:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Which none of the princes of this world knew. For if they had known it, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But, as it is written: That eye hath not seen, nor ear heard: neither hath it entered into the heart of man, what things God hath prepared for them that love him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to us God hath revealed them by his Spirit. For the Spirit searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For what man knoweth the things of a man, but the spirit of a man that is in him? So the things also that are of God, no man knoweth, but the Spirit of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, we have received not the spirit of this world, but the Spirit that is of God: that we may know the things that are given us from God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Which things also we speak: not in the learned words of human wisdom, but in the doctrine of the Spirit, comparing spiritual things with spiritual.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the sensual man perceiveth not these things that are of the Spirit of God. For it is foolishness to him: and he cannot understand, because it is spiritually examined. The sensual man—the spiritual man.... The sensual man is either he who is taken up with sensual pleasures, with carnal and worldly affections; or he who measureth divine mysteries by natural reason, sense, and human wisdom only. Now such a man has little or no notion of the things of God. Whereas the spiritual man is he who, in the mysteries of religion, takes not human sense for his guide: but submits his judgment to the decisions of the church, which he is commanded to hear and obey. For Christ hath promised to remain to the end of the world with his church, and to direct her in all things by the Spirit of truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the spiritual man judgeth all things: and he himself is judged of no man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For who hath known the mind of the Lord, that he may instruct him? But we have the mind of Christ. 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 They must not contend about their teachers, who are but God’s ministers and accountable to him. Their works shall be tried by fire.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I, brethren, could not speak to you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal. As unto little ones in Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I gave you milk to drink, not meat: for you were not able as yet. But neither indeed are you now able: for you are yet carnal.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For, whereas there is among you envying and contention, are you not carnal and walk you not according to man?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For while one saith: I indeed am of Paul: and another: I am of Apollo: are you not men? What then is Apollo and what is Paul?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The ministers of him whom you have believed: and to every one as the Lord hath given.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I have planted, Apollo watered: but God gave the increase.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, neither he that planteth is any thing, nor he that watereth: but God that giveth the increase.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now he that planteth and he that watereth, are one. And every man shall receive his own reward, according to his own labour.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we are God’s coadjutors. You are God’s husbandry: you are God’s building.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: According to the grace of God that is given to me, as a wise architect, I have laid the foundation: and another buildeth thereon. But let every man take heed how he buildeth thereupon.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For other foundation no man can lay, but that which is laid: which is Christ Jesus.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, if any man build upon this foundation, gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, stubble: Upon this foundation.... The foundation is Christ and his doctrine: or the true faith in him, working through charity. The building upon this foundation gold, silver, and precious stones, signifies the more perfect preaching and practice of the gospel; the wood, hay, and stubble, such preaching as that of the Corinthian teachers (who affected the pomp of words and human eloquence) and such practice as is mixed with much imperfection, and many lesser sins. Now the day of the Lord, and his fiery trial, (in the particular judgment immediately after death,) shall make manifest of what sort every man’s work has been: of which, during this life, it is hard to make a judgment. For then the fire of God’s judgment shall try every man’s work. And they, whose works, like wood, hay, and stubble, cannot abide the fire, shall suffer loss; these works being found to be of no value; yet they themselves, having built upon the right foundation, (by living and dying in the true faith and in the state of grace, though with some imperfection,) shall be saved yet so as by fire; being liable to this punishment, by reason of the wood, hay, and stubble, which was mixed with their building.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Every man’s work shall be manifest. For the day of the Lord shall declare it, because it shall be revealed in fire. And the fire shall try every man’s work, of what sort it is.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man’s work abide, which he hath built thereupon, he shall receive a reward.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man’s work burn, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved, yet so as by fire.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man violate the temple of God, him shall God destroy. For the temple of God is holy, which you are.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man deceive himself. If any man among you seem to be wise in this world, let him become a fool, that he may be wise.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. For it is written: I will catch the wise in their own craftiness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And again: The Lord knoweth the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man therefore glory in men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For all things are yours, whether it be Paul or Apollo or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come. For all are yours.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And you are Christ’s. And Christ is God’s. 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 God’s ministers are not to be judged. He reprehends their boasting of their preachers and describes the treatment the apostles every where met with.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let a man so account of us as of the ministers of Christ and the dispensers of the mysteries of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Here now it is required among the dispensers that a man be found faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to me it is a very small thing to be judged by you or by man’s day. But neither do I judge my own self.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I am not conscious to myself of anything. Yet am I not hereby justified: but he that judgeth me is the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, judge not before the time: until the Lord come, who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkness and will make manifest the counsels of the hearts. And then shall every man have praise from God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But these things, brethren, I have in a figure transferred to myself and to Apollo, for your sakes: that in us you may learn that one be not puffed up against the other for another, above that which is written.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For who distinguisheth thee? Or what hast thou that thou hast not received, and if thou hast received, why dost thou glory, as if thou hadst not received it?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are now full: you are now become rich: you reign without us; and I would to God you did reign, that we also might reign with you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I think that God hath set forth us apostles, the last, as it were men appointed to death. We are made a spectacle to the world and to angels and to men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ: we are weak, but you are strong: you are honourable, but we without honour.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Even unto this hour we both hunger and thirst and are naked and are buffeted and have no fixed abode.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And we labour, working with our own hands. We are reviled: and we bless. We are persecuted: and we suffer it.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We are blasphemed: and we entreat. We are made as the refuse of this world, the offscouring of all, even until now.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I write not these things to confound you: but I admonish you as my dearest children.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if you have ten thousand instructors in Christ, yet not many fathers. For in Christ Jesus, by the gospel, I have begotten you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, I beseech you, be ye followers of me as I also am of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For this cause have I sent to you Timothy, who is my dearest son and faithful in the Lord. Who will put you in mind of my ways, which are in Christ Jesus: as I teach every where in every church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As if I would not come to you, so some are puffed up.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I will come to you shortly, if the Lord will: and will know, not the speech of them that are puffed up, but the power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the kingdom of God is not in speech, but in power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What will you? Shall I come to you with a rod? Or in charity and in the spirit of meekness? 1 Corinthians Chapter 5 He excommunicates the incestuous adulterer and admonishes them to purge out the old leaven.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: It is absolutely heard that there is fornication among you and such fornication as the like is not among the heathens: that one should have his father’s wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And you are puffed up and have not rather mourned: that he might be taken away from among you that hath done this thing.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I indeed, absent in body but present in spirit, have already judged, as though I were present, him that hath so done,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, you being gathered together and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To deliver such a one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Your glorying is not good. Know you not that a little leaven corrupteth the whole lump?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Purge out the old leaven, that you may be a new paste, as you are unleavened. For Christ our pasch is sacrificed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, let us feast, not with the old leaven, nor with the leaven of malice and wickedness: but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I wrote to you in an epistle not to keep company with fornicators.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I mean not with the fornicators of this world or with the covetous or the extortioners or the servers of idols: otherwise you must needs go out of this world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now I have written to you, not to keep company, if any man that is named a brother be a fornicator or covetous or a server of idols or a railer or a drunkard or an extortioner: with such a one, not so much as to eat.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For what have I to do to judge them that are without? Do not you judge them that are within?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For them that are without, God will judge. Put away the evil one from among yourselves. 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 He blames them for going to law before unbelievers. Of sins that exclude from the kingdom of heaven. The evil of fornication.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Dare any of you, having a matter against another, go to be judged before the unjust: and not before the saints?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that the saints shall judge this world? And if the world shall be judged by you, are you unworthy to judge the smallest matters?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that we shall judge angels? How much more things of this world?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If therefore you have judgments of things pertaining to this world, set them to judge who are the most despised in the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak to your shame. Is it so that there is not among you any one wise man that is able to judge between his brethren?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But brother goeth to law with brother: and that before unbelievers.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Already indeed there is plainly a fault among you, that you have law suits one with another. Why do you not rather take wrong? Why do you not rather suffer yourselves to be defrauded? A fault.... Lawsuits can hardly ever be without a fault, on the one side or the other; and oftentimes on both sides.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But you do wrong and defraud: and that to your brethren.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that the unjust shall not possess the kingdom of God? Do not err: Neither fornicators nor idolaters nor adulterers:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Nor the effeminate nor liers with mankind nor thieves nor covetous nor drunkards nor railers nor extortioners shall possess the kingdom of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And such some of you were. But you are washed: but you are sanctified: but you are justified: in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and the Spirit of our God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All things are lawful to me: but all things are not expedient. All things are lawful to me: but I will not be brought under the power of any. All things are lawful, etc.... That is, all indifferent things are indeed lawful, inasmuch as they are not prohibited; but oftentimes they are not expedient; as in the case of lawsuits, etc. And much less would it be expedient to be enslaved by an irregular affection to any thing, how indifferent soever.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Meat for the belly and the belly for the meats: but God shall destroy both it and them. But the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord: and the Lord for the body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now God hath both raised up the Lord, and will raise us up also by his power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that your bodies are the members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid!

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or know you not that he who is joined to a harlot is made one body? For they shall be, saith he, two in one flesh.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he who is joined to the Lord is one spirit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Fly fornication. Every sin that a man doth is without the body: but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or know you not that your members are the temple of the Holy Ghost, who is in you, whom you have from God: and you are not your own?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you are bought with a great price. Glorify and bear God in your body. 1 Corinthians Chapter 7 Lessons relating to marriage and celibacy. Virginity is preferable to a married state.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning the things whereof you wrote to me: It is good for a man not to touch a woman.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But for fear of fornication, let every man have his own wife: and let every woman have her own husband. Have his own wife.... That is, keep to his wife, which he hath. His meaning is not to exhort the unmarried to marry: on the contrary, he would have them rather continue as they are. (Ver. 7:8.) But he speaks here to them that are already married; who must not depart from one another, but live together as they ought to do in the marriage state.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let the husband render the debt to his wife: and the wife also in like manner to the husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The wife hath not power of her own body: but the husband. And in like manner the husband also hath not power of his own body: but the wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Defraud not one another, except, perhaps, by consent, for a time, that you may give yourselves to prayer: and return together again, lest Satan tempt you for your incontinency.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I speak this by indulgence, not by commandment. By indulgence.... That is, by a condescension to your weakness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I would that all men were even as myself. But every one hath his proper gift from God: one after this manner, and another after that.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I say to the unmarried and to the widows: It is good for them if they so continue, even as I.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if they do not contain themselves, let them marry. For it is better to marry than to be burnt. If they do not contain, etc.... This is spoken of such as are free, and not of such as, by vow, have given their first faith to God; to whom if they will use proper means to obtain it, God will never refuse the gift of continency. Some translators have corrupted this text, by rendering it, if they cannot contain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But to them that are married, not I, but the Lord, commandeth that the wife depart not from her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if she depart, that she remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband. And let not the husband put away his wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For to the rest I speak, not the Lord. If any brother hath a wife that believeth not and she consent to dwell with him: let him not put her away. I speak, not the Lord.... Viz., by any express commandment, or ordinance.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if any woman hath a husband that believeth not and he consent to dwell with her: let her not put away her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the believing wife: and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the believing husband. Otherwise your children should be unclean: but now they are holy. Is sanctified.... The meaning is not, that the faith of the husband or the wife is of itself sufficient to put the unbelieving party, or their children, in the state of grace and salvation; but that it is very often an occasion of their sanctification, by bringing them to the true faith.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if the unbeliever depart, let him depart. For a brother or sister is not under servitude in such cases. But God hath called us in peace.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For how knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband? Or how knowest thou, O man, whether thou shalt save thy wife?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But as the Lord hath distributed to every one, as God hath called every one: so let him walk. And so in all churches I teach.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Is any man called, being circumcised? Let him not procure uncircumcision. Is any man called in uncircumcision? Let him not be circumcised.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Circumcision is nothing and uncircumcision is nothing: but the observance of the commandments of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let every man abide in the same calling in which he was called.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wast thou called, being a bondman? Care not for it: but if thou mayest be made free, use it rather.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that is called in the Lord, being a bondman, is the freeman of the Lord. Likewise he that is called, being free, is the bondman of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You are bought with a price: be not made the bondslaves of men.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Brethren, let every man, wherein he was called, therein abide with God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now, concerning virgins, I have no commandment of the Lord: but I give counsel, as having obtained mercy of the Lord, to be faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I think therefore that this is good for the present necessity: that it is good for a man so to be.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Art thou bound to a wife? Seek not to be loosed. Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if thou take a wife, thou hast not sinned. And if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned: nevertheless, such shall have tribulation of the flesh. But I spare you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: This therefore I say, brethren: The time is short. It remaineth, that they also who have wives be as if they had none:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And they that weep, as though they wept not: and they that rejoice, as if they rejoiced not: and they that buy as if they possessed not:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And they that use this world, as if they used it not. For the fashion of this world passeth away.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I would have you to be without solicitude. He that is without a wife is solicitous for the things that belong to the Lord: how he may please God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he that is with a wife is solicitous for the things of the world: how he may please his wife. And he is divided.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the unmarried woman and the virgin thinketh on the things of the Lord: that she may be holy both in body and in spirit. But she that is married thinketh on the things of the world: how she may please her husband.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And this I speak for your profit, not to cast a snare upon you, but for that which is decent and which may give you power to attend upon the Lord, without impediment.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man think that he seemeth dishonoured with regard to his virgin, for that she is above the age, and it must so be: let him do what he will. He sinneth not if she marry. Let him do what he will; he sinneth not, etc.... The meaning is not, as libertines would have it, that persons may do what they will and not sin, provided they afterwards marry; but that the father, with regard to the giving his virgin in marriage, may do as he pleaseth; and that it will be no sin to him if she marry.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that hath determined, being steadfast in his heart, having no necessity, but having power of his own will: and hath judged this in his heart, to keep his virgin, doth well.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore both he that giveth his virgin in marriage doth well: and he that giveth her not doth better.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: A woman is bound by the law as long as her husband liveth: but if her husband die, she is at liberty. Let her marry to whom she will: only in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But more blessed shall she be, if she so remain, according to my counsel. And I think that I also have the spirit of God. 1 Corinthians Chapter 8 Though an idol be nothing, yet things offered up to idols are not to be eaten, for fear of scandal.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning those things that are sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge puffeth up: but charity edifieth. Knowledge puffeth up, etc.... Knowledge, without charity and humility, serveth only to puff persons up.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if any man think that he knoweth any thing, he hath not yet known as he ought to know.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man love God, the same is known by him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But as for the meats that are sacrificed to idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world and that there is no God but one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For although there be that are called gods, either in heaven or on earth (for there be gods many and lords many): Gods many, etc.... Reputed for such among the heathens.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yet to us there is but one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we unto him: and one Lord Jesus Christ, by whom are all things, and we by him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But there is not knowledge in every one. For some until this present, with conscience of the idol, eat as a thing sacrificed to an idol: and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But meat doth not commend us to God. For neither, if we eat, shall we have the more: nor, if we eat not, shall we have the less.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But take heed lest perhaps this your liberty become a stumblingblock to the weak.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if a man see him that hath knowledge sit at meat in the idol’s temple, shall not his conscience, being weak, be emboldened to eat those things which are sacrificed to idols?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And through thy knowledge shall the weak brother perish, for whom Christ hath died?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now when you sin thus against the brethren and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, if meat scandalize my brother, I will never eat flesh, lest I should scandalize my brother. If meat scandalize.... That is, if my eating cause my brother to sin. 1 Corinthians Chapter 9 The apostle did not make use of his power of being maintained at the charges of those to whom he preached, that he might give no hindrance to the gospel. Of running in the race and striving for the mastery.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Am not I free? Am not I an apostle? Have not I seen Christ Jesus our Lord? Are not you my work in the Lord?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if unto others I be not an apostle, but yet to you I am. For you are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: My defence with them that do examine me is this.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Have not we power to eat and to drink?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Have we not power to carry about a woman, a sister as well as the rest of the apostles and the brethren of the Lord and Cephas? A woman, a sister.... Some erroneous translators have corrupted this text by rendering it, a sister, a wife: whereas, it is certain, St. Paul had no wife (chap. 7 ver. 7, 8) and that he only speaks of such devout women, as, according to the custom of the Jewish nation, waited upon the preachers of the gospel, and supplied them with necessaries.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or I only and Barnabas, have not we power to do this?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Who serveth as a soldier, at any time, at his own charges? Who planteth a vineyard and eateth not of the fruit thereof? Who feedeth the flock and eateth not of the milk of the flock?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
