Text: Speak I these things according to man? Or doth not the law also say; these things?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For it is written in the law of Moses: Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn. Doth God take care for oxen?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or doth he say this indeed for our sakes? For these things are written for our sakes: that he that plougheth, should plough in hope and he that thrasheth, in hope to receive fruit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If we have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we reap your carnal things?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If others be partakers of this power over you, why not we rather? Nevertheless, we have not used this power: but we bear all things, lest we should give any hindrance to the gospel of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that they who work in the holy place eat the things that are of the holy place; and they that serve the altar partake with the altar?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So also the Lord ordained that they who preach the gospel should live by the gospel.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I have used none of these things. Neither have I written these things, that they should be so done unto me: for it is good for me to die rather than that any man should make my glory void.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if I preach the gospel, it is no glory to me: for a necessity lieth upon me. For woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel. It is no glory.... That is, I have nothing to glory of.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if I do this thing willingly, I have a reward: but if against my will, a dispensation is committed to me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What is my reward then? That preaching the gospel, I may deliver the gospel without charge, that I abuse not my power in the gospel.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For whereas I was free as to all, I made myself the servant of all, that I might gain the more.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I became to the Jews a Jew, that I might gain the Jews:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To them that are under the law, as if I were under the law, (whereas myself was not under the law,) that I might gain them that were under the law. To them that were without the law, as if I were without the law, (whereas I was not without the law of God, but was in the law of Christ,) that I might gain them that were without the law.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To the weak I became weak, that I might gain the weak. I became all things to all men, that I might save all.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I do all things for the gospel’s sake, that I may be made partaker thereof.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Know you not that they that run in the race, all run indeed, but one receiveth the prize. So run that you may obtain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And every one that striveth for the mastery refraineth himself from all things. And they indeed that they may receive a corruptible crown: but we an incorruptible one.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I therefore so run, not as at an uncertainty: I so fight, not as one beating the air.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I chastise my body and bring it into subjection: lest perhaps, when I have preached to others, I myself should become a castaway. I chastise, etc.... Here St. Paul shews the necessity of self-denial and mortification, to subdue the flesh, and its inordinate desires. 1 Corinthians Chapter 10 By the example of the Israelites, he shews that we are not to build too much upon favours received but to avoid their sins and fly from the service of idols and from things offered to idols.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I would not have you ignorant, brethren, that our fathers were all under the cloud: and all passed through the sea.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And all in Moses were baptized, in the cloud and in the sea: In Moses.... Under the conduct of Moses, they received baptism in figure, by passing under the cloud, and through the sea; and they partook of the body and blood of Christ in figure, by eating of the manna, (called here a spiritual food because it was a figure of the true bread which comes down from heaven,) and drinking the water, miraculously brought out of the rock, called here a spiritual rock, because it was also a figure of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And did all eat the same spiritual food:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And all drank the same spiritual drink: (And they drank of the spiritual rock that followed them: and the rock was Christ.)

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But with most of them God was not well pleased: for they were overthrown in the desert.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now these things were done in a figure of us, that we should not covet evil things, as they also coveted.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither become ye idolaters, as some of them, as it is written: The people sat down to eat and drink and rose up to play.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither let us commit fornication, as some of them committed fornication: and there fell in one day three and twenty thousand.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither let us tempt Christ, as some of them tempted and perished by the serpents.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Neither do you murmur, as some of them murmured and were destroyed by the destroyer.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now all these things happened to them in figure: and they are written for our correction, upon whom the ends of the world are come. The ends of the world.... That is, the last ages.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, he that thinketh himself to stand, let him take heed lest he fall.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no temptation take hold on you, but such as is human. And God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that which you are able: but will make also with temptation issue, that you may be able to bear it. Or.... no temptation hath taken hold of you.... or come upon you as yet, but what is human, or incident to man. Issue.... or a way to escape.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, my dearly beloved, fly from the service of idols.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I speak as to wise men: judge ye yourselves what I say.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The chalice of benediction which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? And the bread which we break, is it not the partaking of the body of the Lord? Which we bless.... Here the apostle puts them in mind of their partaking of the body and blood of Christ in the sacred mysteries, and becoming thereby one mystical body with Christ. From whence he infers, ver. 21, that they who are made partakers with Christ, by the eucharistic sacrifice and sacrament, must not be made partakers with devils by eating of the meats sacrificed to them.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we, being many, are one bread, one body: all that partake of one bread. One bread.... or, as it may be rendered, agreeably both to the Latin and Greek, because the bread is one, all we, being many, are one body, who partake of that one bread. For it is by our communicating with Christ, and with one another, in this blessed sacrament, that we are formed into one mystical body; and made, as it were, one bread, compounded of many grains of corn, closely united together.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Behold Israel according to the flesh. Are not they that eat of the sacrifices partakers of the altar?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What then? Do I say that what is offered in sacrifice to idols is any thing? Or that the idol is any thing?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But the things which the heathens sacrifice, they sacrifice to devils and not to God. And I would not that you should be made partakers with devils.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You cannot drink the chalice of the Lord and the chalice of devils: you cannot be partakers of the table of the Lord and of the table of devils.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he? All things are lawful for me: but all things are not expedient.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All things are lawful for me: but all things do not edify.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man seek his own, but that which is another’s.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, eat: asking no question for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The earth is the Lord’s and the fulness thereof.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any of them that believe not, invite you, and you be willing to go: eat of any thing that is set before you, asking no question for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man say: This has been sacrificed to idols: do not eat of it, for his sake that told it and for conscience’ sake.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Conscience I say, not thy own, but the other’s. For why is my liberty judged by another man’s conscience?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If I partake with thanksgiving, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, whether you eat or drink, or whatsoever else you do, do all to the glory of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Be without offence to the Jew, and to the Gentiles and to the church of God:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: As I also in all things please all men, not seeking that which is profitable to myself but to many: that they may be saved. 1 Corinthians Chapter 11 Women must have a covering over their heads. He blameth the abuses of their love feasts and upon that occasion treats of the Blessed Sacrament.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Be ye followers of me, as I also am of Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I praise you, brethren, that in all things you are mindful of me and keep my ordinances as I have delivered them to you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I would have you know that the head of every man is Christ: and the head of the woman is the man: and the head of Christ is God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Every man praying or prophesying with his head covered disgraceth his head.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But every woman praying or prophesying with her head not covered disgraceth her head: for it is all one as if she were shaven.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if a woman be not covered, let her be shorn. But if it be a shame to a woman to be shorn or made bald, let her cover her head.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The man indeed ought not to cover his head: because he is the image and glory of God. But the woman is the glory of the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the man is not of the woman: but the woman of the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the man was not created for the woman: but the woman for the man.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore ought the woman to have a power over her head, because of the angels. A power.... that is, a veil or covering, as a sign that she is under the power of her husband: and this, the apostle adds, because of the angels, who are present in the assemblies of the faithful.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But yet neither is the man without the woman, nor the woman without the man, in the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For as the woman is of the man, so also is the man by the woman: but all things of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You yourselves judge. Doth it become a woman to pray unto God uncovered?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Doth not even nature itself teach you that a man indeed, if he nourish his hair, it is a shame unto him?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if a woman nourish her hair, it is a glory to her; for her hair is given to her for a covering.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man seem to be contentious, we have no such custom, nor the Church of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I ordain: not praising you, that you come together, not for the better, but for the worse.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For first of all I hear that when you come together in the church, there are schisms among you. And in part I believe it.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For there must be also heresies: that they also, who are approved may be made manifest among you. There must be also heresies.... By reason of the pride and perversity of man’s heart; not by God’s will or appointment; who nevertheless draws good out of this evil, manifesting, by that occasion, who are the good and firm Christians, and making their faith more remarkable.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: When you come therefore together into one place, it is not now to eat the Lord’s supper. The Lord’s supper.... So the apostle here calls the charity feasts observed by the primitive Christians; and reprehends the abuses of the Corinthians, on these occasions; which were the more criminal, because these feasts were accompanied with the celebrating of the eucharistic sacrifice and sacrament.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For every one taketh before his own supper to eat. And one indeed is hungry and another is drunk.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What, have you no houses to eat and to drink in? Or despise ye the church of God and put them to shame that have not? What shall I say to you? Do I praise you? In this I praise you not.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you, that the Lord Jesus, the same night in which he was betrayed, took bread,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And giving thanks, broke and said: Take ye and eat: This is my body, which shall be delivered for you. This do for the commemoration of me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In like manner also the chalice, after he had supped, saying: This chalice is the new testament in my blood. This do ye, as often as you shall drink, for the commemoration of me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For as often as you shall eat this bread and drink the chalice, you shall shew the death of the Lord, until he come.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, whosoever shall eat this bread, or drink the chalice of the Lord unworthily, shall be guilty of the body and of the blood of the Lord. Or drink.... Here erroneous translators corrupted the text, by putting and drink (contrary to the original) instead of or drink. Guilty of the body, etc., not discerning the body, etc.... This demonstrates the real presence of the body and blood of Christ, even to the unworthy communicant; who otherwise could not be guilty of the body and blood of Christ, or justly condemned for not discerning the Lord’s body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But let a man prove himself: and so let him eat of that bread and drink of the chalice. Drink of the chalice.... This is not said by way of command, but by way of allowance, viz., where and when it is agreeable to the practice and discipline of the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily eateth and drinketh judgment to himself, not discerning the body of the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore are there many infirm and weak among you: and many sleep.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if we would judge ourselves, we should not be judged.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But whilst we are judged, we are chastised by the Lord, that we be not condemned with this world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, my brethren, when you come together to eat, wait for one another.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man be hungry, let him eat at home; that you come not together unto judgment. And the rest I will set in order, when I come. 1 Corinthians Chapter 12 Of the diversity of spiritual gifts. The members of the mystical body, like those of the natural body, must mutually cherish one another.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning spiritual things, my brethren, I would not have you ignorant.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: You know that when you were heathens, you went to dumb idols, according as you were led.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, I give you to understand that no man, speaking by the Spirit of God, saith Anathema to Jesus. And no man can say The Lord Jesus, but by the Holy Ghost.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now there are diversities of graces, but the same Spirit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And there are diversities of ministries, but the same Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And there are diversities of operations, but the same God, who worketh all in all.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the manifestation of the Spirit is given to every man unto profit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To one indeed, by the Spirit, is given the word of wisdom: and to another, the word of knowledge, according to the same Spirit:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To another, faith in the same spirit: to another, the grace of healing in one Spirit:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: To another the working of miracles: to another, prophecy: to another, the discerning of spirits: to another, diverse kinds of tongues: to another, interpretation of speeches.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But all these things, one and the same Spirit worketh, dividing to every one according as he will.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For as the body is one and hath many members; and all the members of the body, whereas they are many, yet are one body: So also is Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For in one Spirit were we all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Gentiles, whether bond or free: and in one Spirit we have all been made to drink.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For the body also is not one member, but many.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If the foot should say: Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body: Is it therefore not of the body?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if the ear should say: Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body: Is it therefore not of the body?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If the whole body were the eye, where would be the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where would be the smelling?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now God hath set the members, every one of them, in the body as it hath pleased him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if they all were one member, where would be the body?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now there are many members indeed, yet one body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the eye cannot say to the hand: I need not thy help. Nor again the head to the feet: I have no need of you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yea, much more those that seem to be the more feeble members of the body are more necessary.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And such as we think to be the less honourable members of the body, about these we put more abundant honour: and those that are our uncomely parts have more abundant comeliness.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But our comely parts have no need: but God hath tempered the body together, giving to that which wanted the more abundant honour.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That there might be no schism in the body: but the members might be mutually careful one for another.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if one member suffer any thing, all the members suffer with it: or if one member glory, all the members rejoice with it.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now you are the body of Christ and members of member.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And God indeed hath set some in the church; first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly doctors: after that miracles: then the graces of healings, helps, governments, kinds of tongues, interpretations of speeches.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all doctors?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Are all workers of miracles? Have all the grace of healing? Do all speak with tongues? Do all interpret?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But be zealous for the better gifts. And I shew unto you yet a more excellent way. 1 Corinthians Chapter 13 Charity is to be preferred before all gifts.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if I should have prophecy and should know all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I should have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if I should distribute all my goods to feed the poor, and if I should deliver my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Charity is patient, is kind: charity envieth not, dealeth not perversely, is not puffed up,

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Is not ambitious, seeketh not her own, is not provoked to anger, thinketh no evil:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth with the truth:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Charity never falleth away: whether prophecies shall be made void or tongues shall cease or knowledge shall be destroyed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For we know in part: and we prophesy in part.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But when that which is perfect is come, that which is in part shall be done away.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: When I was a child, I spoke as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child. But, when I became a man, I put away the things of a child.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: We see now through a glass in a dark manner: but then face to face. Now I know in part: but then I shall know even as I am known.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And now there remain faith, hope, and charity, these three: but the greatest of these is charity. 1 Corinthians Chapter 14 The gift of prophesying is to be preferred before that of speaking strange tongues.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Follow after charity, be zealous for spiritual gifts; but rather that you may prophesy. Prophesy.... That is, declare or expound the mysteries of faith.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he that speaketh in a tongue speaketh not unto men, but unto God: for no man heareth. Yet by the Spirit he speaketh mysteries. Not unto men.... Viz., so as to be heard, that is, so as to be understood by them.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But he that prophesieth speaketh to men unto edification and exhortation and comfort.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: He that speaketh in a tongue edifieth himself: but he that prophesieth, edifieth the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I would have you all to speak with tongues, but rather to prophesy. For greater is he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues: unless perhaps he interpret, that the church may receive edification.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now, brethren, if I come to you speaking with tongues, what shall I profit you, unless I speak to you either in revelation or in knowledge or in prophecy or in doctrine?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Even things without life that give sound, whether pipe or harp, except they give a distinction of sounds, how shall it be known what is piped or harped?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So likewise you, except you utter by the tongue plain speech, how shall it be known what is said? For you shall be speaking into the air.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: There are, for example, so many kinds of tongues in this world: and none is without voice.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If then I know not the power of the voice, I shall be to him to whom I speak a barbarian: and he that speaketh a barbarian to me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So you also, forasmuch as you are zealous of spirits, seek to abound unto the edifying of the church. Of spirits.... Of spiritual gifts.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And therefore he that speaketh by a tongue, let him pray that he may interpret.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prayeth: but my understanding is without fruit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: What is it then? I will pray with the spirit, I will pray also with the understanding, I will sing with the spirit, I will sing also with the understanding.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Else, if thou shalt bless with the spirit, how shall he that holdeth the place of the unlearned say, Amen, to thy blessing? Because he knoweth not what thou sayest. Amen.... The unlearned, not knowing that you are then blessing, will not be qualified to join with you by saying Amen to your blessing. The use or abuse of strange tongues, of which the apostle here speaks, does not regard the public liturgy of the church, (in which strange tongues were never used,) but certain conferences of the faithful, ver. 26, etc., in which, meeting together, they discovered to one another their various miraculous gifts of the Spirit, common in those primitive times; amongst which the apostle prefers that of prophesying before that of speaking strange tongues, because it was more to the public edification. Where also not, that the Latin, used in our liturgy, is so far from being a strange or unknown tongue, that it is perhaps the best known tongue in the world.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For thou indeed givest thanks well: but the other is not edified.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I thank my God I speak with all your tongues.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But in the church I had rather speak five words with my understanding, that I may instruct others also: than ten thousand words in a tongue.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Brethren, do not become children in sense. But in malice be children: and in sense be perfect.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In the law it is written: In other tongues and other lips I will speak to this people: and neither so will they hear me, saith the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore tongues are for a sign, not to believers but to unbelievers: but prophecies, not to unbelievers but to believers.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If therefore the whole church come together into one place, and all speak with tongues, and there come in unlearned persons or infidels, will they not say that you are mad?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if all prophesy, and there come in one that believeth not or an unlearned person, he is convinced of all: he is judged of all.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The secrets of his heart are made manifest. And so, falling down on his face, he will adore God, affirming that God is among you indeed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: How is it then, brethren? When you come together, every one of you hath a psalm, hath a doctrine, hath a revelation, hath a tongue, hath an interpretation: let all things be done to edification.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any speak with a tongue, let it be by two, or at the most by three, and in course: and let one interpret.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if there be no interpreter, let him hold his peace in the church and speak to himself and to God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And let the prophets speak, two or three: and let the rest judge.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any thing be revealed to another sitting, let the first hold his peace.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For you may all prophesy, one by one, that all may learn and all may be exhorted.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For God is not the God of dissension, but of peace: as also I teach in all the churches of the saints.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let women keep silence in the churches: for it is not permitted them to speak but to be subject, as also the law saith.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if they would learn anything, let them ask their husbands at home. For it is a shame for a woman to speak in the church.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Or did the word of God come out from you? Or came it only unto you?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any seem to be a prophet or spiritual, let him know the things that I write to you, that they are the commandments of the Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if any man know not, he shall not be known.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Wherefore, brethren, be zealous to prophesy: and forbid not to speak with tongues.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But let all things be done decently and according to order. 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Christ’s resurrection and ours. The manner of our resurrection.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I make known unto you, brethren, the gospel which I preached to you, which also you have received and wherein you stand.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: By which also you are saved, if you hold fast after what manner I preached unto you, unless you have believed in vain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I delivered unto you first of all, which I also received: how that Christ died for our sins, according to the scriptures:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And that he was buried: and that he rose again the third day, according to the scriptures:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And that he was seen by Cephas, and after that by the eleven.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Then was he seen by more than five hundred brethren at once: of whom many remain until this present, and some are fallen asleep.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: After that, he was seen by James: then by all the apostles.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And last of all, he was seen also by me, as by one born out of due time.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I am the least of the apostles, who am not worthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But by the grace of God, I am what I am. And his grace in me hath not been void: but I have laboured more abundantly than all they. Yet not I, but the grace of God with me:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For whether I or they, so we preach: and so you have believed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now if Christ be preached, that he arose again from the dead, how do some among you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But if there be no resurrection of the dead, then Christ is not risen again.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if Christ be not risen again, then is our preaching vain: and your faith is also vain.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God: because we have given testimony against God, that he hath raised up Christ, whom he hath not raised up, if the dead rise not again.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For if the dead rise not again, neither is Christ risen again.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if Christ be not risen again, your faith is vain: for you are yet in your sins.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Then they also that are fallen asleep in Christ are perished.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But now Christ is risen from the dead, the firstfruits of them that sleep:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For by a man came death: and by a man the resurrection of the dead.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And as in Adam all die, so also in Christ all shall be made alive.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But every one in his own order: the firstfruits, Christ: then they that are of Christ, who have believed in his coming.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Afterwards the end: when he shall have delivered up the kingdom to God and the Father: when he shall have brought to nought all principality and power and virtue.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For he must reign, until he hath put all his enemies under his feet.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And the enemy, death, shall be destroyed last: For he hath put all things under his feet. And whereas he saith:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All things are put under him; undoubtedly, he is excepted, who put all things under him.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And when all things shall be subdued unto him, then the Son also himself shall be subject unto him that put all things under him, that God may be all in all. The Son also himself shall be subject unto him.... That is, the Son will be subject to the Father, according to his human nature, even after the general resurrection; and also the whole mystical body of Christ will be entirely subject to God, obeying him in every thing.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Otherwise, what shall they do that are baptized for the dead, if the dead rise not again at all? Why are they then baptized for them? That are baptized for the dead.... Some think the apostle here alludes to a ceremony then in use; but others, more probably, to the prayers and penitential labours, performed by the primitive Christians for the souls of the faithful departed; or to the baptism of afflictions and sufferings undergone for sinners spiritually dead.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Why also are we in danger every hour?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: I die daily, I protest by your glory, brethren, which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If (according to man) I fought with beasts at Ephesus, what doth it profit me, if the dead rise not again? Let us eat and drink, for to morrow we shall die. Let us eat and drink, etc.... That is, if we did not believe that we were to rise again from the dead, we might live like the impious and wicked, who have no belief in the resurrection.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Be not seduced: Evil communications corrupt good manners.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Awake, ye just, and sin not. For some have not the knowledge of God. I speak it to your shame.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But some man will say: How do the dead rise again? Or with what manner of body shall they come?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Senseless man, that which thou sowest is not quickened, except it die first.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And that which thou sowest, thou sowest not the body that shall be: but bare grain, as of wheat, or of some of the rest.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But God giveth it a body as he will: and to every seed its proper body.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All flesh is not the same flesh: but one is the flesh of men, another of beasts, another of birds, another of fishes.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And there are bodies celestial and bodies terrestrial: but, one is the glory of the celestial, and another of the terrestrial.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: One is the glory of the sun, another the glory of the moon, and another the glory of the stars. For star differeth from star in glory.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: So also is the resurrection of the dead. It is sown in corruption: it shall rise in incorruption.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: It is sown in dishonour: it shall rise in glory. It is sown in weakness: it shall rise in power.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: It is sown a natural body: it shall rise a spiritual body. If there be a natural body, there is also a spiritual body, as it is written:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The first man Adam was made into a living soul; the last Adam into a quickening spirit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Yet that was not first which is spiritual, but that which is natural: afterwards that which is spiritual.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The first man was of the earth, earthly: the second man, from heaven, heavenly.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Such as is the earthly, such also are the earthly: and such as is the heavenly, such also are they that are heavenly.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, as we have borne the image of the earthly, let us bear also the image of the heavenly.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot possess the kingdom of God: neither shall corruption possess incorruption.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Behold, I tell you a mystery. We shall all indeed rise again: but we shall not all be changed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet: for the trumpet shall sound and the dead shall rise again incorruptible. And we shall be changed.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For this corruptible must put on incorruption: and this mortal must put on immortality.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And when this mortal hath put on immortality, then shall come to pass the saying that is written: Death is swallowed up in victory.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: O death, where is thy victory? O death, where is thy sting?

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now the sting of death is sin: and the power of sin is the law.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But thanks be to God, who hath given us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Therefore, my beloved brethren, be ye steadfast and unmoveable: always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labour is not in vain in the Lord. 1 Corinthians Chapter 16 Of collection of alms. Admonitions and salutations.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now concerning the collections that are made for the saints: as I have given order to the churches of Galatia, so do ye also.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: On the first day of the week, let every one of you put apart with himself, laying up what it shall well please him: that when I come, the collections be not then to be made.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And when I shall be with you, whomsoever you shall approve by letters, them will I send to carry your grace to Jerusalem.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And if it be meet that I also go, they shall go with me.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now I will come to you, when I shall have passed through Macedonia. For I shall pass through Macedonia.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And with you perhaps I shall abide, or even spend the winter: that you may bring me on my way whithersoever I shall go.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For I will not see you now by the way: for I trust that I shall abide with you some time, if the Lord permit.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: But I will tarry at Ephesus, until Pentecost.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For a great door and evident is opened unto me: and many adversaries.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Now if Timothy come, see that he be with you without fear: for he worketh the work of the Lord, as I also do.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let no man therefore despise him: but conduct ye him on his way in peace, that he may come to me. For I look for him with the brethren.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And touching our brother Apollo, I give you to understand that I much entreated him to come unto you with the brethren: and indeed it was not his will at all to come at this time. But he will come when he shall have leisure.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Watch ye: stand fast in the faith: do manfully and be strengthened.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: Let all your things be done in charity.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I beseech you, brethren, you know the house of Stephanus, and of Fortunatus, and of Achaicus, that they are the firstfruits of Achaia, and have dedicated themselves to the ministry of the saints:

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: That you also be subject to such and to every one that worketh with us and laboureth.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: And I rejoice in the presence of Stephanus and Fortunatus and Achaicus: because that which was wanting on your part, they have supplied.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: For they have refreshed both my spirit and yours. Know them, therefore, that are such.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The churches of Asia salute you. Aquila and Priscilla salute you much in the Lord, with the church that is in their house, with whom I also lodge.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: All the brethren salute you. Salute one another with a holy kiss.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The salutation of me Paul, with my own hand.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: If any man love not our Lord Jesus Christ, let him be anathema, maranatha. Let him be anathema, maranatha.... Anathema signifies here a thing accursed. Maran-atha, which, according to St. Jerome and St. Chrysostom, signify, ‘The Lord is come’ already, and therefore is to be taken as an admonition to those who doubted of the resurrection, and to put them in mind that Christ, the judge of the living and the dead, is come already. Others explain Maran-atha: ‘May our Lord come’, that is, to judge and punish those with exemplary judgments and punishments, that do not love the Lord Jesus Christ.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.

Book: The First Epistle of St. Paul to the Corinthians
Text: My charity be with you all in Christ Jesus. Amen.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: In the days of Assuerus, who reigned from India to Ethiopia over a hundred and twenty seven provinces:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: When he sat on the throne of his kingdom, the city Susan was the capital of his kingdom.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now in the third year of his reign he made a great feast for all the princes, and for his servants, for the most mighty of the Persians, and the nobles of the Medes, and the governors of the provinces in his sight,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That he might shew the riches of the glory of his kingdom, and the greatness, and boasting of his power, for a long time, to wit, for a hundred and fourscore days.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when the days of the feast were expired, he invited all the people that were found in Susan, from the greatest to the least: and commanded a feast to be made seven days in the court of the garden, and of the wood, which was planted by the care and the hand of the king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And there were hung up on every side sky coloured, and green, and violet hangings, fastened with cords of silk, and of purple, which were put into rings of ivory, and were held up with marble pillars. The beds also were of gold and silver, placed in order upon a floor paved with porphyry and white marble: which was embellished with painting of wonderful variety.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And they that were invited, drank in golden cups, and the meats were brought in divers vessels one after another. Wine also in abundance and of the best was presented, as was worthy of a king’s magnificence.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Neither was there any one to compel them to drink that were not willing, but as the king had appointed, who set over every table one of his nobles, that every man might take what he would.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Also Vasthi the queen made a feast for the women in the palace, where king Assuerus was used to dwell.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now on the seventh day, when the king was merry, and after very much drinking was well warmed with wine, he commanded Mauman, and Bazatha, and Harbona, and Bagatha, and Abgatha, and Zethar, and Charcas, the seven eunuchs that served in his presence,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: To bring in queen Vasthi before the king, with the crown set upon her head, to shew her beauty to all the people and the princes: for she was exceeding beautiful.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But she refused, and would not come at the king’s commandment, which he had signified to her by the eunuchs. Whereupon the king, being angry, and inflamed with a very great fury,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Asked the wise men, who according to the custom of the kings, were always near his person, and all he did was by their counsel, who knew the laws, and judgments of their forefathers:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: (Now the chief and nearest him were, Charsena, and Sethar, and Admatha, and Tharsis, and Mares, and Marsana, and Mamuchan, seven princes of the Persians and of the Medes, who saw the face of the king, and were used to sit first after him:)

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: What sentence ought to pass upon Vasthi the queen, who had refused to obey the commandment of king Assuerus, which he had sent to her by the eunuchs?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Mamuchan answered, in the hearing of the king and the princes: Queen Vasthi hath not only injured the king, but also all the people and princes that are in all the provinces of king Assuerus.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For this deed of the queen will go abroad to all women, so that they will despise their husbands, and will say: King Assuerus commanded that queen Vasthi should come in to him, and she would not.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And by this example all the wives of the princes of the Persians and the Medes will slight the commandments of their husbands: wherefore the king’s indignation is just.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: If it please thee, let an edict go out from thy presence, and let it be written according to the law of the Persians and of the Medes, which must not be altered, that Vasthi come in no more to the king, but another, that is better than her, be made queen in her place.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And let this be published through all the provinces of thy empire, (which is very wide,) and let all wives, as well of the greater as of the lesser, give honour to their husbands.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: His counsel pleased the king, and the princes: and the king did according to the counsel of Mamuchan.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he sent letters to all the provinces of his kingdom, as every nation could hear and read, in divers languages and characters, that the husbands should be rulers and masters in their houses: and that this should be published to every people. Esther Chapter 2 Esther is advanced to be queen. Mardochai detecteth a plot against the king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: After this, when the wrath of king Assuerus was appeased, he remembered Vasthi, and what she had done and what she had suffered:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king’s servants and his officers said: Let young women be sought for the king, virgins and beautiful,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And let some persons be sent through all the provinces to look for beautiful maidens and virgins: and let them bring them to the city of Susan, and put them into the house of the women under the hand of Egeus the eunuch, who is the overseer and keeper of the king’s women: and let them receive women’s ornaments, and other things necessary for their use.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And whosoever among them all shall please the king’s eyes, let her be queen instead of Vasthi. The word pleased the king: and he commanded it should be done as they had suggested.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: There was a man in the city of Susan, a Jew, named Mardochai, the son of Jair, the son of Semei, the son of Cis, of the race of Jemini,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Who had been carried away from Jerusalem at the time that Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon carried away Jechonias king of Juda,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he had brought up his brother’s daughter Edissa, who by another name was called Esther: now she had lost both her parents: and was exceeding fair and beautiful. And her father and mother being dead, Mardochai adopted her for his daughter.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when the king’s ordinance was noised abroad, and according to his commandment many beautiful virgins were brought to Susan, and were delivered to Egeus the eunuch: Esther also among the rest of the maidens was delivered to him to be kept in the number of the women.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And she pleased him, and found favour in his sight. And he commanded the eunuch to hasten the women’s ornaments, and to deliver to her her part, and seven of the most beautiful maidens of the king’s house, and to adorn and deck out both her and her waiting maids.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And she would not tell him her people nor her country. For Mardochai had charged her to say nothing at all of that:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he walked every day before the court of the house, in which the chosen virgins were kept, having a care for Esther’s welfare, and desiring to know what would befall her.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now when every virgin’s turn came to go in to the king, after all had been done for setting them off to advantage, it was the twelfth month: so that for six months they were anointed with oil of myrrh, and for other six months they used certain perfumes and sweet spices.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when they were going in to the king, whatsoever they asked to adorn themselves they received: and being decked out, as it pleased them, they passed from the chamber of the women to the king’s chamber.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And she that went in at evening, came out in the morning, and from thence she was conducted to the second house, that was under the hand of Susagaz the eunuch, who had the charge over the king’s concubines: neither could she return any more to the king, unless the king desired it, and had ordered her by name to come.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And as the time came orderly about, the day was at hand, when Esther, the daughter of Abihail the brother of Mardochai, whom he had adopted for his daughter, was to go in to the king. But she sought not women’s ornaments, but whatsoever Egeus the eunuch the keeper of the virgins had a mind, he gave her to adorn her. For she was exceeding fair, and her incredible beauty made her appear agreeable and amiable in the eyes of all.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So she was brought to the chamber of king Assuerus the tenth month, which is called Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king loved her more than all the women, and she had favour and kindness before him above all the women, and he set the royal crown on her head, and made her queen instead of Vasthi.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he commanded a magnificent feast to be prepared for all the princes, and for his servants, for the marriage and wedding of Esther, And he gave rest to all the provinces, and bestowed gifts according to princely magnificence.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when the virgins were sought the second time, and gathered together, Mardochai stayed at the king’s gate,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Neither had Esther as yet declared her country and people, according to his commandment. For whatsoever he commanded, Esther observed: and she did all things in the same manner as she was wont at that time when he brought her up a little one.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: At that time, therefore, when Mardochai abode at the king’s gate, Bagathan and Thares, two of the king’s eunuchs, who were porters, and presided in the first entry of the palace, were angry: and they designed to rise up against the king, and to kill him.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Mardochai had notice of it, and immediately he told it to queen Esther: and she to the king in Mardochai’s name, who had reported the thing unto her.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: It was inquired into, and found out: and they were both hanged on a gibbet. And it was put in the histories, and recorded in the chronicles before the king. Esther Chapter 3 Aman, advanced by the king, is offended at Mardochai, and therefore procureth the king’s decree to destroy the whole nation of the Jews.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: After these things, king Assuerus advanced Aman, the son of Amadathi, who was of the race of Agag: and he set his throne above all the princes that were with him.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And all the king’s servants, that were at the doors of the palace, bent their knees, and worshipped Aman: for so the emperor had commanded them, only Mardochai did not bend his knee, nor worship him.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king’s servants that were chief at the doors of the palace, said to him: Why dost thou alone not observe the king’s commandment?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when they were saying this often, and he would not hearken to them, they told Aman, desirous to know whether he would continue in his resolution: for he had told them that he was a Jew.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now when Aman had heard this, and had proved by experience that Mardochai did not bend his knee to him, nor worship him, he was exceeding angry.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he counted it nothing to lay his hands upon Mardochai alone: for he had heard that he was of the nation of the Jews, and he chose rather to destroy all the nation of the Jews that were in the kingdom of Assuerus.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: In the first month (which is called Nisan) in the twelfth year of the reign of Assuerus, the lot was cast into an urn, which in Hebrew is called Phur, before Aman, on what day and what month the nation of the Jews should be destroyed: and there came out the twelfth month, which is called Adar.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Aman said to king Assuerus: There is a people scattered through all the provinces of thy kingdom, and separated one from another, that use new laws and ceremonies, and moreover despise the king’s ordinances: and thou knowest very well that it is not expedient for thy kingdom that they should grow insolent by impunity.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: If it please thee, decree that they may be destroyed, and I will pay ten thousand talents to thy treasurers.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king took the ring that he used, from his own hand, and gave it to Aman, the son of Amadathi of the race of Agag, the enemy of the Jews,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he said to him: As to the money which thou promisest, keep it for thyself: and as to the people, do with them as seemeth good to thee.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king’s scribes were called in the first month Nisan, on the thirteenth day of the same month: and they wrote, as Aman had commanded, to all the king’s lieutenants, and to the judges of the provinces, and of divers nations, as every nation could read, and hear according to their different languages, in the name of king Assuerus: and the letters, sealed with his ring,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Were sent by the king’s messengers to all provinces, to kill and destroy all the Jews, both young and old, little children, and women, in one day, that is, on the thirteenth of the twelfth month, which is called Adar, and to make a spoil of their goods.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the contents of the letters were to this effect, that all provinces might know and be ready against that day.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The couriers that were sent made haste to fulfil the king’s commandment. And immediately the edict was hung up in Susan, the king and Aman feasting together, and all the Jews that were in the city weeping. Esther Chapter 4 Mardochai desireth Esther to petition the king for the Jews. They join in fasting and prayer.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Now when Mardochai had heard these things, he rent his garments, and put on sackcloth, strewing ashes on his head and he cried with a loud voice in the street in the midst of the city, shewing the anguish of his mind.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he came lamenting in this manner even to the gate of the palace: for no one clothed with sackcloth might enter the king’s court.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And in all provinces, towns, and places, to which the king’s cruel edict was come, there was great mourning among the Jews, with fasting, wailing, and weeping, many using sackcloth and ashes for their bed.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then Esther’s maids and her eunuchs went in, and told her. And when she heard it she was in a consternation and she sent a garment, to clothe him, and to take away the sackcloth: but he would not receive it.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And she called for Athach the eunuch, whom the king had appointed to attend upon her, and she commanded him to go to Mardochai, and learn of him why he did this.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Athach going out went to Mardochai, who was standing in the street of the city, before the palace gate:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Mardochai told him all that had happened, how Aman had promised to pay money into the king’s treasures, to have the Jews destroyed.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: He gave him also a copy of the edict which was hanging up in Susan, that he should shew it to the queen, and admonish her to go in to the king, and to entreat him for her people.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Athach went back and told Esther all that Mardochai had said.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: She answered him, and bade him say to Mardochai:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: All the king’s servants, and all the provinces that are under his dominion, know, that whosoever, whether man or woman, cometh into the king’s inner court, who is not called for, is immediately to be put to death without any delay: except the king shall hold out the golden sceptre to him, in token of clemency, that so he may live. How then can I go in to the king, who for these thirty days now have not been called unto him?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when Mardochai had heard this,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: He sent word to Esther again, saying: Think not that thou mayst save thy life only, because thou art in the king’s house, more than all the Jews:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For if thou wilt now hold thy peace, the Jews shall be delivered by some other occasion: and thou, and thy father’s house shall perish. And who knoweth whether thou art not therefore come to the kingdom, that thou mightest be ready in such a time as this?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And again Esther sent to Mardochai in these words:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Go, and gather together all the Jews whom thou shalt find in Susan, and pray ye for me. Neither eat nor drink for three days and three nights: and I with my handmaids will fast in like manner, and then I will go in to the king, against the law, not being called, and expose myself to death and to danger.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So Mardochai went, and did all that Esther had commanded him. Esther Chapter 5 Esther is graciously received: she inviteth the king and Aman to dinner, Aman prepareth a gibbet for Mardochai.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And on the third day Esther put on her royal apparel, and stood in the inner court of the king’s house, over against the king’s hall: now he sat upon his throne in the hall of the palace, over against the door of the house.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when he saw Esther the queen standing, she pleased his eyes, and he held out toward her the golden sceptre, which he held in his hand and she drew near, and kissed the top of his sceptre.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said to her: What wilt thou, queen Esther? what is thy request? if thou shouldst even ask one half of the kingdom, it shall be given to thee.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But she answered: If it please the king, I beseech thee to come to me this day, and Aman with thee to the banquet which I have prepared.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said forthwith: Call ye Aman quickly, that he may obey Esther’s will. So the king and Aman came to the banquet which the queen had prepared for them.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said to her, after he had drunk wine plentifully: What dost thou desire should be given thee? and for what thing askest thou? although thou shouldst ask the half of my kingdom, thou shalt have it.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Esther answered: My petition and request is this:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: If I have found favour in the king’s sight, and if it please the king to give me what I ask, and to fulfil my petition: let the king and Aman come to the banquet which I have prepared them, and to morrow I will open my mind to the king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So Aman went out that day joyful and merry. And when he saw Mardochai sitting before the gate of the palace, and that he not only did not rise up to honour him, but did not so much as move from the place where he sat, he was exceedingly angry:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But dissembling his anger, and returning into his house, he called together to him his friends, and Zares his wife:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he declared to them the greatness of his riches, and the multitude of his children, and with how great glory the king had advanced him above all his princes and servants.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And after this he said: Queen Esther also hath invited no other to the banquet with the king, but me: and with her I am also to dine to morrow with the king:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And whereas I have all these things, I think I have nothing, so long as I see Mardochai the Jew sitting before the king’s gate.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then Zares his wife, and the rest of his friends answered him: Order a great beam to be prepared, fifty cubits high, and in the morning speak to the king, that Mardochai may be hanged upon it, and so thou shalt go full of joy with the king to the banquet. The counsel pleased him, and he commanded a high gibbet to be prepared. Esther Chapter 6 The king hearing of the good service done him by Mardochai, commandeth Aman to honour him next to the king, which he performeth.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: That night the king passed without sleep, and he commanded the histories and chronicles of former times to be brought him. And when they were reading them before him,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: They came to that place where it was written, how Mardochai had discovered the treason of Bagathan and Thares the eunuchs, who sought to kill king Assuerus.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when the king heard this, he said: What honour and reward hath Mardochai received for this fidelity? His servants and ministers said to him: He hath received no reward at all. No reward at all.... He received some presents from the king, chap. 12.5; but these were so inconsiderable in the opinion of the courtiers, that they esteemed them as nothing at all.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said immediately: Who is in the court? for Aman was coming in to the inner court of the king’s house, to speak to the king, that he might order Mardochai to be hanged upon the gibbet, which was prepared for him.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: The servants answered: Aman standeth in the court, and the king said: Let him come in.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when he was come in, he said to him: What ought to be done to the man whom the king is desirous to honour? But Aman thinking in his heart, and supposing that the king would honour no other but himself,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Answered: The man whom the king desireth to honour,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Ought to be clothed with the king’s apparel, and to be set upon the horse that the king rideth upon, and to have the royal crown upon his head,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And let the first of the king’s princes and nobles hold his horse, and going through the street of the city, proclaim before him and say: Thus shall he be honoured, whom the king hath a mind to honour.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said to him: Make haste and take the robe and the horse, and do as thou hast spoken to Mardochai the Jew, who sitteth before the gates of the palace. Beware thou pass over any of those things which thou hast spoken.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So Aman took the robe and the horse, and arraying Mardochai in the street of the city, and setting him on the horse, went before him, and proclaimed: This honour is he worthy of, whom the king hath a mind to honour.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But Mardochai returned to the palace gate: and Aman made haste to go to his house, mourning and having his head covered:

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And he told Zares his wife, and his friends, all that had befallen him. And the wise men whom he had in counsel, and his wife answered him: If Mardochai be of the seed of the Jews, before whom thou hast begun to fall, thou canst not resist him, but thou shalt fall in his sight.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: As they were yet speaking, the king’s eunuchs came, and compelled him to go quickly to the banquet which the queen had prepared. Esther Chapter 7 Esther’s petition for herself and her people: Aman is hanged upon the gibbet he had prepared for Mardochai.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So the king and Aman went in, to drink with the queen.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king said to her again the second day, after he was warm with wine: What is thy petition, Esther, that it may be granted thee? and what wilt thou have done: although thou ask the half of my kingdom, thou shalt have it.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then she answered: If I have found favour in thy sight, O king, and if it please thee, give me my life for which I ask, and my people for which I request.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For we are given up, I and my people, to be destroyed, to be slain, and to perish. And would God we were sold for bondmen and bondwomen: the evil might be borne with, and I would have mourned in silence: but now we have an enemy, whose cruelty redoundeth upon the king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And king Assuerus answered and said: Who is this, and of what power, that he should do these things?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Esther said: It is this Aman that is our adversary and most wicked enemy. Aman hearing this was forthwith astonished, not being able to bear the countenance of the king and of the queen.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But the king being angry rose up, and went from the place of the banquet into the garden set with trees. Aman also rose up to entreat Esther the queen for his life, for he understood that evil was prepared for him by the king.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And when the king came back out of the garden set with trees, and entered into the place of the banquet, he found Aman was fallen upon the bed on which Esther lay, and he said: He will force the queen also in my presence, in my own house. The word was not yet gone out of the king’s mouth, and immediately they covered his face.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Harbona, one of the eunuchs that stood waiting on the king, said: Behold the gibbet which he hath prepared for Mardochai, who spoke for the king, standeth in Aman’s house, being fifty cubits high. And the king said to him: Hang him upon it.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So Aman was hanged on the gibbet, which he had prepared for Mardochai: and the king’s wrath ceased. Esther Chapter 8 Mardochai is advanced: Aman’s letters are reversed.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: On that day king Assuerus gave the house of Aman, the Jews’ enemy, to queen Esther, and Mardochai came in before the king. For Esther had confessed to him that he was her uncle.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king took the ring which he had commanded to be taken again from Aman, and gave it to Mardochai. And Esther set Mardochai over her house.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And not content with these things, she fell down at the king’s feet and wept, and speaking to him besought him, that he would give orders that the malice of Aman the Agagite, and his most wicked devices which he had invented against the Jews, should be of no effect.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But he, as the manner was, held out the golden sceptre with his hand, which was the sign of clemency: and she arose up and stood before him,

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And said: If it please the king, and if I have found favour in his sight, and my request be not disagreeable to him, I beseech thee, that the former letters of Aman the traitor and enemy of the Jews, by which he commanded that they should be destroyed in all the king’s provinces, may be reversed by new letters.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: For how can I endure the murdering and slaughter of my people?

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And king Assuerus answered Esther the queen, and Mardochai the Jew: I have given Aman’s house to Esther, and I have commanded him to be hanged on a gibbet, because he durst lay hands on the Jews.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Write ye therefore to the Jews, as it pleaseth you in the king’s name, and seal the letters with my ring. For this was the custom, that no man durst gainsay the letters which were sent in the king’s name, and were sealed with his ring.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: Then the king’s scribes and secretaries were called for (now it was the time of the third month which is called Siban) the three and twentieth day of the month, and letters were written, as Mardochai had a mind, to the Jews, and to the governors, and to the deputies, and to the judges, who were rulers over the hundred and twenty-seven provinces, from India even to Ethiopia: to province and province, to people and people, according to their languages and characters, and to the Jews, according as they could read and hear.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And these letters which were sent in the king’s name, were sealed with his ring, and sent by posts: who were to run through all the provinces, to prevent the former letters with new messages.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And the king gave orders to them, to speak to the Jews in every city, and to command them to gather themselves together, and to stand for their lives, and to kill and destroy all their enemies with their wives and children and all their houses, and to take their spoil.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And one day of revenge was appointed through all the provinces, to wit, the thirteenth of the twelfth month Adar.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And this was the content of the letter, that it should be notified in all lands and peoples that were subject to the empire of king Assuerus, that the Jews were ready to be revenged of their enemies.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So the swift posts went out carrying the messages, and the king’s edict was hung up in Susan.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And Mardochai going forth out of the palace, and from the king’s presence, shone in royal apparel, to wit, of violet and sky colour, wearing a golden crown on his head, and clothed with a cloak of silk and purple. And all the city rejoiced, and was glad.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: But to the Jews, a new light seemed to rise, joy, honour, and dancing.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: And in all peoples, cities, and provinces, whithersoever the king’s commandments came, there was wonderful rejoicing, feasts and banquets, and keeping holy day: Insomuch that many of other nations and religion, joined themselves to their worship and ceremonies. For a great dread of the name of the Jews had fallen upon all. Esther Chapter 9 The Jews kill their enemies that would have killed them. The days of Phurim are appointed to be kept holy.

Book: The Book of Esther
Text: So on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which as we have said above is called Adar, when all the Jews were designed to be massacred, and their enemies were greedy after their blood, the case being altered, the Jews began to have the upper hand, and to revenge themselves of their adversaries. To revenge, etc.... The Jews on this occasion, by authority from the king, were made executioners of the public justice, for punishing by death a crime worthy of death, viz., a malicious conspiracy for extirpating their whole nation.
